NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended September the 30th 1952.

Principal

Dated October the 1st 1952.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at Fort Frances this 1st Oct. 1952.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Ottawa, August 28th., 1911.

Madam,-

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th. instant with reference to the teaching of Hygiene at the Fort Resolution Boarding School. In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased that the introduction of this subject in the school is proving of interest to yourself and the Indian children. With reference to the bath tubs I regret to inform you that the Department cannot supply them. Under the new contract with Boarding Schools which went into effect on April 1st. last, the Church authorities are called upon to supply all the necessary equipment. As the grant to your school is now $135.00 per annum no doubt if you will communicate with the proper authorities they will be willing to supply you with the bath tubs, which would appear to be essential.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Memo:

Bishop Breynat called at the Office last week in connection with the proposed construction of a boarding school and hospital at Fort Resolution.

Bishop Breynat has given me verbally all the particulars regarding the type of construction which can be considered in this part of the country. I will gladly furnish the draftsmen with all of the information required when plans are being prepared for this building.

Dr. Scott,

You will remember that an ice house and cold storage has been requested for the Resolution Indian Residential School. At one time, the school management wanted a refrigerating plant; but the Department has explained that the best we could do would be the standard equipment for Indian residential schools. This will cost approximately $2,000. Father Lefebvre has had a chat with Mr. Orr regarding the matter, and I wish to recommend that a plan and a list of material be prepared at the present time. Most of the lumber can be secured in the North, but some of the material should be purchased in Edmonton in the near future. The activity could proceed if the Department would pay for the materials that have to be secured now from this year's Vote and then an item placed in the Estimates for the construction and other materials. Memorandum for File:

With reference to the accounts for the refrigerator which has been erected under Father Lefebvre's supervision at the Fort Resolution Indian Residential School, it should be stated that accounts of Revillon Freres, now defunct, amounting to $623.68, were forwarded by Father Lefebvre in May last. These never reached the Department and, consequently, no cheque was issued. When Father Lefebvre returned from the Mackenzie River at the end of July, he paid the Revillon Freres by allowing them to draw on him and, accordingly, he has no receipt. It is possible that the liquidator will be able to give a receipt. This account of $623.68 included the freight as far as Waterways. ($474.56 plus freight $149.12).

Revillon Freres drew on Father Lefebvre for four other accounts for material, as follows:

- $114.64
- $236.00
- $98.31
- $381.68

Father Lefebvre will try to secure receipts for these also from the liquidator as the accounts have been paid.

Father Lefebvre has paid the Edmonton Paint & Glass Co.'s account amounting to $474.77, and two accounts of the Ashdown Hardware $44.80 and $6.80. There is no freight on the last four accounts from Revillon's nor on the accounts from the Edmonton Paint & Glass and Ashdown Hardware. The accounts from the last two concerns will be receipted and forwarded to the Department.

These accounts, which Father Lefebvre will endeavour to have receipted, total $1,884.88. In addition to these, there have been heavy charges for freight and there is, also, an account for pipe clay. I told Father Lefebvre that the $1,884.88 would be re-imbursement to him and, also, the account for clay. There has been no promise that we will bear any more than $2,100. of the cost of the refrigerator.

This generator set consists of a Fairbanks-Morse 8 h.p. Special Electric Engine, direct connected through flexible coupling to a 3½ k.w. 125 volt compound wound direct current generator.

The engine is the well known type "Z" four cycle, with Fairbanks-Morse self-driven high tension magneto-enclosed crank case, extra heavy flywheels and other refinements adapting it to electric lighting service. It is completely self contained, with built-in cooling fan and steam condensing radiator. There is a negative and constant cooling system, and consists of a capacious cast iron reservoir bolted to the cylinder, the evaporated steam from which passes to the radiator, where it is condensed by the action of an enclosed fan mounted inside of the flywheel, and thence returned to the engine jacket. Replacement of cooling water is seldom ever necessary, and the temperature is automatically maintained at the best point for efficient operation.

The fuel tank is enclosed in the engine base, but can, if desired, be installed outside of the building, a fuel pump being then provided. Engine operates on kerosene, but gasoline can be used if more conveniently procured.

Generator is a sturdy, slow speed machine—operating at engine speed of 550 revolutions per minute. Being compound wound, the voltage will remain constant, regardless of the number of lights in use.

The regulation is such that the plant can be operated directly on the line, without battery, and there will be no flickering of the lights.

This is a very desirable plant for picture theatres, rinks, public halls, etc. In rinks, the cooling system will be found decidedly convenient, as only a pail or two of water is required to cool it, or an antifreezing mixture can be used quite as effectively, all evaporation being condensed and returned.

Sir,

I have the honour to send, under same cover the invoices from the Canadian Fairbanks Co., Winnipeg, covering the purchase of the electric plant, engine generator, batteries, and switchboard, for the use of Agency school, and violet rays lamp at the school hospital. The special invoice sent from the Department asking for information relates to the switchboard, which was sent separately later.

I beg to state that the goods were received and the plant new installed, but the service of shipping the goods from that firm was very unsatisfactory. The engine and generator was shipped and the switchboard sent only a month later, causing all kinds of inconvenience to us, having to wait for the installation, the rheostat the most important part of the switchboard not mounted as promised and received only at the beginning of September when we had wired for it. No instructions were sent until the 12th of September, the gasoline tank on the engine was leaking and had to be repaired, the rheostat started after many troubles, and finally the generator not working at all, caused by a wire in the generator winding altogether short, and this specially giving us trouble for days before the trouble could be found. This missing wire was either done before shipment or in transit, but the machine looked in perfect condition when received. Finally we had the troubles repaired and the plant is now working very satisfactory. The Mission is now installing their wiring for lights and quartz light.

The plant had to be installed at the Agency, at the request of Bishop Breymat due to better ground conditions for foundations, and care of the plant, and the service will be given from the Agency on a proportion basis, with the quartz light installed at the Convent until the hospital is erected.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

C. Bourget M.D.

Dear Sirs:

Your letter of Oct. 17th has been referred to the writer in connection with the second paragraph which you quote Mr. Bourget's report in connection with the Lighting Plant purchased from this Office. It is quite true that this shipment was not handled in the way in which we like to take care of these orders, a fact which we very sincerely regret, and which has been fully explained to Mr. Bourget both by Telegram and Letter. It seems to us only fair to ourselves to mention that the question of the leaking Gasoline Tank, and missing generator Wire, are two things for which we are not responsible. Since this plant was assembled and tested in our own shop in Winnipeg, we are quite confident that it was absolutely in first class shape when it left here and not only that but considerable time and expense was devoted to the making of a strong rugged crate, as we realized the transportation conditions in the far north would require this.

Nevertheless we very much regret that Mr. Bourget found it necessary to include an adverse report on the handling of this order and we can assure you that no effort will be spared to make certain that future orders from the Department of Indian Affairs will be handled in such a way that there will be no cause for complaint.

Madam:

Dear Sir:

A few days after I wired you from Lebret on the 17th of January, a letter from Fort Resolution informed me that our old St-Joseph's Residential School had nearly been destroyed by fire which was caused by the explosion of the acetylene plant in use satisfactorily for over twenty years.

The school was prevented from being a complete loss by the efforts of the priests, lay-brothers and the people of the settlement who were in the vicinity of the building at the time. This accident renders more urgent the necessity of installing an electric plant next spring, and I trust you will see your way clear to include the $6000 required for the plant in this year's estimates.

Hoping to receive a favorable reply at the above address and thanking you in advance, I remain,

Respectfully yours,

Sir,

On the 27th of December last, I sent you a wire with regard to a carbide explosion that happened at the St. Joseph Indian Residential School. It was simply miraculous that the whole building was not gutted by fire.

As this carbide is their only means of lighting the establishment, I suggested that electricity be installed all through the building. The Mission's answer was that they could not afford it, but possibly, if they had any help, they might do it early this spring.

Consequently, my suggestion to the Department would be that one-half of the expenses be carried by the Department and I am told the Mission would carry the other half.

Kindly let me know at your earliest convenience what the Department is prepared to do in this connection.

June 1st 1936

By H.W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Following our conversation of May 29th., I wish to respectfully insist on the necessity of an electrical plant for the school at Fort Resolution, to replace the acetylene apparatus which, as you know, exploded last year. It was due to the energy and the courage of the Sisters and Brothers that the building was saved from complete destruction. For safety's sake it seems most desirable that an electrical plant be installed at once and ready for next winter.

From an interview with the Minister of the Interior on May 29th, I am persuaded that, as you have suggested, authorization could easily be obtained for a grant to be taken from the funds for general expenses, without having recourse to any additional appropriation.

I would highly appreciate it if a reply were sent without delay to Edmonton, 9916 --110th St., where I shall stop for a few days and have the opportunity of ordering the required material.

Yours respectfully,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

The acetylene gas plant at the Indian Residential School, Fort Resolution, North West Territories exploded last winter. This school is under the control of Right Reverend G. Breynat, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie, who made application for the Department to supply a new lighting plant for the school. In connection with this request, His Lordship wrote the Deputy Superintendent General on June first as follows:-

"From an interview with the Minister of the Interior on May 29th, I am persuaded that, as you have suggested, authorization could easily be obtained for a grant to be taken from the funds for general expenses, without having recourse to any additional appropriation."

Dr. McGill replied on June 9th:-

"Our Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year was considerably reduced and no funds to pay the cost of a lighting plant were provided for this school. I am not able, at the present time, to state definitely whether funds for the purpose can be found in the appropriation. This will depend on the savings that can be effected during the year. Early next winter, the Department will be aware what funds there may be available. At that time, if it is possible,

- favourable
favourable consideration will be given to providing the funds required to cover the cost of the above mentioned equipment."

The Department is now in receipt of a telegram from Bishop Breynat, pointing out the necessity for an electric light plant in this school and stating that it should be supplied before the school re-opens, about September first. His Lordship has a quotation from the Lister Company, of $3,500, for a suitable electric installation at this school.

As pointed out in the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of June 9th, no funds were specially provided in the current year's appropriation for an electric light plant at the Fort Resolution School, but funds for the purpose could be obtained from an amount that is included in our Appropriation for unforeseen expenses. There is no doubt that a lighting system is necessary at this school, and I would appreciate your concurrence in authorizing Bishop Breynat to proceed with the Lister Company installation, at the price mentioned above.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council:

The undersigned has the honour to report that the acetylene gas plant for lighting purposes at the Indian Residential School, Fort Resolution, North West Territories, a church-owned institution, exploded last winter and that it was necessary to supply a new lighting plant for the school.

Right Reverend G. Breynat, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie, under whose auspices the school is conducted, requested that a Lister Diesel lighting plant be obtained and all buildings wired. The Department agreed to supply the lighting equipment, at a cost of Thirty-five Hundred Dollars ($3,500.00). Funds for the purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1936-37.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of Thirty-five Hundred Dollars ($3,500.00) for the purpose above mentioned.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The Fort Resolution Indian Residential School, conducted under the auspices of Right Reverend G. Breynat, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie, is located at Fort Resolution, North West Territories. During the winter of 1935, the acetylene gas plant, which was used for lighting purposes, exploded. His Lordship made application for the supplying of a new lighting plant for the school, of the Lister Diesel type, and necessary wiring and pole line to service the buildings. The cost of supplying and installing the equipment was $3,500.00.

Funds, to pay the account covering the cost to the above amount, are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1936-37.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 7th October 1936.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 30th September, 1936, from the Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, stating that the acetylene gas plant for lighting purposes at the Indian Residential School, Fort Resolution, North West Territories, a church-owned institution, exploded last winter and that it was necessary to supply a new lighting plant for the school;

That Right Reverend G. Breynat, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie, under whose auspices the school is conducted, requested that a Lister Diesel lighting plant be obtained and all buildings wired;

Dear Mr. McGill:

Your letter of November 10th to hand.

With regard to my request for a grant to install an electric plant at our Providence Mission Indian Residential School, I note that my request reached you too late to be included in the estimates for the current fiscal year.

May I be allowed to state that I have never been notified of the proper time to present our demands for financial assistance. It is true that, owing to my continual travelling in the North, I might have been too late anyway. However, if it is too late to have provision made in the regular estimates for this year, may I hope that you will find your way clear to have such provision included in the next supplementary estimates?

Indeed, it would be unfair to us should the four residential schools of my Vicariate be deprived of their share of the assistance regularly given by your Department for needy equipment, repairs and improvements. It is obvious that fire protection an electrical plant is badly needed in our Providence School, and the per capita grant is hardly sufficient to cover the current expenses of the year.

May I take this opportunity to ask you if the Department has taken into consideration my two previous demands:

1 - An outright grant of $2500. for the building of our school at Chipewyan.

2 - An adjustment of our per capita grant so as to have it on the same basis as that allowed for many years past at the Anglican school of Carcross and also at St-Paul's Hostel, the children of which attend the public school in Dawson.

It seems to me, as you acknowledged it when we discussed the matter in Ottawa, that the same treatment should be granted to us owing to the fact that we have to pay heavy freight rates. At any rate, the two above demands were made in time and thoroughly discussed with your Department for the last two years.

May I hope that your Department has not overlooked to have necessary provision made in the current year's estimates so as to meet our just request.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Bishop of Athabasca.

Dear Madam:

On a recent requisition received for supplies for the Fort Resolution Residential School you requested 1 school desk, 6 chairs and 2 folding tables.

The Department has no objection to supplying the above but before placing the order I desire to advise you that in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39 we have provided an item of $500.00 for general repairs and equipment at the Fort Resolution School. If the desks, chairs and tables are supplied their cost will reduce the amount available for repairs. The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th April, 1938, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That the estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote Number 169, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provide an amount of $34,582.00 for new works, repairs and purchase of equipment for the following Church owned Indian Residential Schools:

(a) ONTARIO
   Spanish Roman Catholic Residential School
   Moose Fort Church of England Residential School

(b) SASKATCHEWAN
   Thunderchild Roman Catholic Residential School

(c) ALBERTA
   Ermineskin Roman Catholic Residential School
   Croward Roman Catholic Residential School
   Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School
   Joseph Roman Catholic Residential School
   St. Albert Roman Catholic Residential School
   Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School
   Vermilion Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Church of England Residential School
   Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School.

(d) NORTHWEST TERRITORIES
   Aklavik Roman Catholic Residential School
   Aklavik Church of England Residential School
   Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School
   Providence Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.

(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA
   Ahousaht United Church Residential School
   Cariboo Roman Catholic Residential School
   Christie Roman Catholic Residential School
   Kitamaat United Church Residential School
   Fort Simpson United Church Residential School
   St Mary's Mission Roman Catholic Residential School
   Squamish Roman Catholic Residential School
That, as these buildings are Church owned, new works, repairs and purchase of equipment constitute a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools of the sum of $34,582.00, same to be chargeable to Vote Number 169, 1938-39, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF FEBRUARY

GENERAL REMARKS

The inspection of school rooms, halls and dormitories and class examinations were carried out at the beginning of the month, along with a general fire drill.

It was gratifying to see the school pupils looking so well fed and generally healthy, when on the 20th a few suffered from La Grippe, which soon developed to serious cases of Influenza affecting most of the school and Fort population.

The first cases of Flu were reported from Rocher River among the widows and destitute Indians of that settlement.

On the 16th of February, I chartered the R.C.Mission plane for the purpose of visiting and treating these sick Indians and providing them with rations. On the same trip I brought a few hundred pounds of flour from the I.D. supply at Resolution to Rocher River where the supply was running low.

To a few exceptions every pupil is or was sick, necessitating the closing of school on February 20th.

Among the pupils, mostly members of the Dog-Rib Band from Fort Rae, were more severely affected and of these, the girls seem to suffer more and have less resistance to the disease.

This epidemic of Flu came with the sudden change to cold weather after a comparatively mild spell.

J. H. Riopel,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

As per instructions received from Archbishop Breynat, I wrote to the Department on November 12th last in connection with the repairs and equipment proposed for the Indian Residential schools located in the MacKenzie diocese for the fiscal year 1940-1941.

In the above mentioned letter, I took for granted that the total amount which was supposed to be allotted in the estimates would be approximately $3500. At least, this was the figure given to me by Mr. Phelan in his office last October. This amount was detailed as follows:

| SCHOOL       | EQUIPMENT |
|--------------|-----------|
| Fort Providence | 1,700.00 |
| Fort Resolution | 1,000.00 |
| Aklavik      | 800.00    |

At the same time, I wrote to the Department for the purchase of a laundry washer destined to the Indian School at Fort Resolution.

It seems that the time has now come to give you more details concerning other equipment, and I have been asked by Archbishop Breynat to submit the attached list covering repairs and equipment needed at the schools of Aklavik and Fort Providence.

The intention of the Archbishop is to repair the ceilings at both schools, as the Spring weather has deteriorated them badly. Therefore, we have prepared a list of the material needed in connection with these repairs, keeping in mind to cut down requirements to the minimum. A few other things needed for the equipment at Aklavik have been added to the list. We hope that the Department will give to it its favourable consideration.

While we have no special recommendations to make as to the firms from which the material might be purchased, we think it advisable to mention that the ordinary spruce lumber could be advantageously purchased from the Mc Innes' Products Corporation at Waterways; the lumber while being of average quality, is much lower in price than that purchased in Edmonton.
We wish to mention that purchases should be made not later than June 15th in order to have the material delivered at Waterways early enough for transportation by the Hudson's Bay Company to Akleivik and Fort Providence.

Dear Father Serrurot:

With reference to your request for a washer for the Fort Resolution Residential School it is noted that you desire it to be equipped with a 1 H.P. electric motor direct current - D.C. - and special switch.

Am I to understand that you intend to operate this from the electric light plant? You could, of course, operate the washer with a small gasoline engine.

Please let me hear from you in this regard at the earliest possible date in order that the purchase of the washer may not be unnecessarily delayed.

Dear Mr Hoey,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th instant dealing with our request for a washer to be purchased in favour of the Fort Resolution Residential School, same to be equipped with a 1 H.P. electric motor direct current. It is noted from your letter that the Department is against the policy of operating any machinery from the electric light plant, for the reason that such operations wear out the batteries and necessitate their replacement earlier than in the normal course of operation.

However, we wish to inform the Department that it has never been our intention, when using any machinery operated by electric power, to depend on our batteries for that. We then supply the necessary power by running the diesel motor connected with the dynamo, so that no extra current over the output of the batteries is ever used. We have this procedure followed in each of our missions, Fort Smith, Fort Resolution, Fort Providence, Aklavik, and from our experience during the past years, we cannot help but saying that our batteries set is lasting as long as any set under normal conditions.

Speaking of the economical viewpoint, we found that it was cheaper to operate thus than to buy small gasoline engine for such machinery. As the Department is aware, diesel crude oil is cheaper than gasoline and one uses less crude oil than gasoline for the same power. On the other hand, the washer contemplated is to be in service once every two weeks only. We therefore feel certain that, cost for cost, it would be more expensive for us to operate such a washer with a gasoline engine than with electric motor, provided the method we follow is applied. Unless the Department has serious objection against it, we insist on having the washer requested for Fort Resolution equipped with a 1 H.P. Electric motor, D.C.

Regarding the last paragraph of your letter, I thank you for forwarding me the report you had received from the Principal of the Fort Resolution School for fiscal year 1939-40. I am giving instructions to Sister Lapointe to complete her report and to have it returned to you as early as possible.

Yours respectfully,

J. Ferruot, O.M.I.,
Bursar.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With reference to repairs and equipment needed at the R.C. Indian Residential Schools of the Mackenzie District, we beg to submit herewith a detailed list of what we would require for the fiscal year 1941-42. This list for each of the four schools has been prepared according to instructions received from His Exc. Archbishop Breynat and it is his wish that the Department would give to it its favorable consideration pending the amount of money appropriated for that purpose.

The suggestions we have been making on these lists with regard to firms from which one or the other of the purchases could be made have no other aim than to give some specifications as to material or equipment requested, without desiring to interfere in any respect with the purchasing branch. It is immaterial for us that the order would be given to this or that firm, provided what we receive would be suitable for our purpose and would be delivered on time by next summer's boats.

In connection with transportation, we felt that the total paid last summer by the Department for freight charges from Waterways, Alta., to each school had the result to curtail to a considerable extent the amount appropriated for purchases. We were somewhat disappointed in seeing that so many hundreds of dollars allotted for repairs and equipment would in fact go to transportation companies operating from Waterways.

Therefore Archbishop Breynat has requested me to point out to the Department that it would be more satisfactory to us if the Department would undertake to pay freight charges as far as Waterways only and would leave it up to us to have it delivered to destination. Such a policy has been followed until last summer and we hope that the Department will have no objection about it. Reason for our asking this is because we undertake every summer to carry ourselves in our own boats most of the freight consigned to our schools down the Mackenzie District, saving thus a valuable amount of money. This policy would enable us to have a larger share spent on the purchases only, instead of having a great proportion of the allotments devoted for paying freight charges to commercial Companies.

La batteuse Champion est vendue d’ordinaire pour être actionnée par un pouvoir de 3 à 7 C.V. suivant les accessoires qu’on y ajoute tels qu’empacheur, élévateur et soufflet. Elle peut aussi être montée sur un camion, à un coût additionnel raisonnable.

La batteuse Forano est la seule parmi les petits modèles de batteuses possédant un chasse-paille spécial. Au lieu d’une tôle perforée ordinaire, le fond du chasse-paille est formé de petites feuilles d’acier pliées, très rigides, posées sur le travers, entre lesquelles il y a assez d’espace pour laisser passer toutes les balles et le grain. Il en résulte une séparation plus rapide, éliminant la perte du grain et assurant une plus longue durée. Les barbillons d’orge ne peuvent s’accumuler sur le fond du chasse-paille, évitant ainsi une perte considérable de bon grain.

Le cylindre est composé de 9 barres ou supports de dents et chaque barre est faite d’une partie de bois entre deux d’acier, lui assurant une grande résistance et une grande souplesse.

Les dents sont à épaulement carré.

Des graisseurs à pression sont fournis sur tous les coussinets.

Une batteuse FORANO est toujours plus facile à maintenir en parfaite condition; elle requiert moins de pouvoir, fait un meilleur travail et si vous faites du battage pour d’autres, elle vous a vite créé une bonne réputation et un revenu assuré.

Nous vous présentons ici la batteuse Forano-Clément, nouveau modèle, unique dans son genre, et le principe est protégé par brevets. L'inventeur est un praticien qui, avec la coopération de nos ingénieurs, a réussi à développer une machine qui dépasse toute attente tant au point de vue qualité que quantité.

Il s'agit d'une batteuse relativement simple de construction, requérant peu de pouvoir et d'une capacité surprenante, considérant le pouvoir requis. Elle est de 4 pieds plus courte que les autres batteuses en bois parce que le chasse-paille est placé au-dessous du crible et le secouage ou la séparation du grain d'avec la paille commence sous le cylindre. Cet item diminue la longueur de 2 pieds comparativement aux autres modèles en bois dont le dessous du cylindre est inutilisé; aussi, la construction du soufflet est-elle extrêmement plate. Le soufflet est posé de manière à être au-dessus de la longueur du moulin, est fixé en sens contraire, c'est-à-dire en travers de la batteuse. Il n'est pas nécessaire d'avoir un talon pour conduire la balle du crible au soufflet car la partie extérieure du crible et du chasse-paille est en ligne avec l'arrière du moulin. De cette façon, tout le matériel tombe directement dans le soufflet, excepté le grain, bien entendu. Ce dernier a pris une autre direction et nous en parlerons plus loin.

Le soufflet est très solidement fixé à la batteuse au moyen de pentures. Pour avoir accès à l'intérieur du moulin, pour changer les passes ou pour tout autre ajustement, vous n'avez qu'à déplacer un taquet à main disposé à cette fin. Nous tenons aussi à attirer l'attention sur la table d'alimentation qui est située au-dessus des essieux. La table d'alimentation est peu étroite, chose appréciable surtout pour une batteuse sans empocheur automatique. C'est donc un modèle pratique pour le battant ambulant qui désire un moulin requérant peu d'espace pour se placer n'importe où, même dans les plus petites granges.

Le fond du chasse-paille est formé de petites feuilles d'acier, pliées, très rigides, entre lesquelles il y a suffisamment d'espace pour laisser passer toutes les balles, les graines ou le grain. Il y a aussi des listières de bois dentelées, qui soulèvent le foin ou la paille et permettent aux graines ou aux grains de s'échapper plus facilement.

CONCLUSIONS DES CONNAISSANTS: La batteuse Forano-Clément est simple et courte, elle fait un travail supérieur à toutes machines jusqu'ici connues et elle devrait être la favorite de tous ceux qui veulent une bonne batteuse, à un prix moyen.

Le crible étant placé au-dessus du chasse-paille, la balle, les graines ou les grains qui ont été séparés du foin ou de la paille, sont conduits au crible au moyen d'un élévateur qui est composé d'une chaîne double sans fin avec palettes, faisant le tour de la batteuse. Le mouvement donné à ce dernier élimine tout danger de congestion, même si le grain est humide.

La fabrication du crible et du chasse-paille est la même que la batteuse Québec excepté que ces derniers sont changés de position. L'empocheur consiste en une petite boîte en-dessous du crible et de la hauteur voulue pour les sacs.

Ce modèle est toujours vendu complet avec soufflet, camion, empocheur et élévateur.

La batteuse Forano-Clément est aussi vendue avec appareil à tréfle, lorsque désiré.

Dear Sir,

Attention Mr. Philip Melan,

Re: Water Tanks for Indian Residential School at Fort Resolution, N.W.T.

When I was in Ottawa last November I mentioned and discussed with you the necessity of having water tanks or reservoirs for the Indian Residential School at Fort Resolution. The wooden tank which has been in use for several years has rotted away and is beyond repair. It has to be replaced or three or four smaller tanks could be installed so as to store a larger quantity of water.

Previously the water level in the bay was high and water was easily available but now due to low water and the danger of it being contaminated if taken too close to the shores, it has to be pumped or carried from a long distance.

I mentioned the installation of smaller tanks because the exit from the basement of the School is too narrow to allow a larger tank and small ones could be put in more convenient places, and the water used for drinking purposes will have to be treated with Chlorinated Lime and one or two tanks could be used for that purpose.

I enquired in Edmonton regarding these tanks and the tinsmith at the Western Steel Co; whom I met through Mr. Wright from the Ashtown Hardware Ltd., recommended corrugated galvanized iron.

Gauge 22 for the sides and Gauge 20 for the bottoms. Each tank, capacity of 1000 gallons, would be six feet in diameter and 5 feet high, made up of two sections. The bottom section would be shipped made up at the shop and the upper section could be riveted and soldered.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant our appropriation has not yet been passed by Parliament but it is hoped to be able to secure the following amounts for the Indian residential schools in the Mackenzie Diocese:

| SCHOOL            | REPAIRS AND IMPROVEMENTS | EQUIPMENT       |
|-------------------|--------------------------|-----------------|
| Fort Resolution   | $300.                    | $600. Desks     |
| Providence Mission| $200.                    | 1,000. Laundry Equipment |
| Holy Angels        | $500.                    |                 |
| Aklavik R.C.      | $300.                    | 500. Refrigerator |

You will understand that owing to present conditions our appropriations have been reduced and consequently the above amounts are all that could be secured for the schools mentioned and I hope will enable you to make necessary repairs and improvements and secure the equipment that is urgently required.

Complete information should be forwarded to this office as early as possible regarding what is wanted in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch. We can arrange for these purchases immediately after the first of April and that will ensure their reaching Waterways soon after, if not before, navigation opens.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Serrurot, O.M.I.,
9916 - 110 Street,
Edmonton, Alta.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We are in receipt of your letter of the 20th inst., dealing with the amounts which the Department is hoping to have appropriated for the fiscal year 1941-42 at the R.C. Indian Residential Schools of the MacKenzie Diocese.

While we appreciate very much your endeavours in trying to have the usual amount appropriated for repairs and equipment, we are under the impression that there is some confusion between specifications mentioned in your letter and demands made by us to the Department on October 31st last.

We detailed repairs and equipment that we wished for the year 1941 and we attached these lists to our letter of the above mentioned date. If you would kindly refer to these lists, you will undoubtedly see what we are expecting of the Department in connection with the amounts to be appropriated for repairs and equipment.

Since these lists were proposed according to the decision of Archbishop Breynat, we would indeed be very glad if the Department could make purchases as specified thereon.

In case you would like another copy of these lists, I shall be very pleased to have one forwarded to you immediately.

As mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter, we feel sure that if purchases are made in April, it will be early enough since it gives time for the material to be delivered at the various schools during the navigation season.

Yours very truly,

FOR THE R.C. EPISCOPAL CORPORATION OF MACKENZIE,

J. Serrurier, O.M.I.,

Dear Sir,

I appreciate very much your letter of January 29th. We are really in need of a good engine here at our Indian school. This motor would be used for visiting our fish nets, for taking the school children more quickly to any destination, as well as for pulling a small rowboat, in which we are able to place all the children safely when taking them for a picnic. It would also facilitate the visits of the children whose parents live along the shores of Great Slave Lake.

I had previously mentioned an outboard because on this lake, it is much easier to get about, than with a boat equipped with an inboard engine. Along the lake shore there are few good sheltered places, especially in the direction of localities where the children's parents...

Memorandum

Mr. R.A. Hoey

With reference to your requisition of the 19th instant, (file 139-1-5) for galvanized iron roofing for the Fort Resolution Indian Residential School, - I may say that owing to wartime restrictions on the use of iron and steel for civilian use, it will be necessary to obtain a permit from the Steel Controllers Office to purchase your requirements.

To facilitate making application for this permit, we should be furnished with the following information:

(a) Size of sheets required

(b) Are the sheets to be corrugated or flat galvanized iron

(c) Are the sheets required to repair an old building, or for roofing a new structure or addition. If the latter, sufficient reasons should be given regarding the necessity for using the iron.

In case we are unsuccessful in obtaining the required permit, please give details of suitable substitute that would be acceptable.

H.J. DAVIDSON

Re - Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School

I inspected the above mentioned school on June 7th and 8th, examined the building and observed the instruction given by the staff.

Representatives of the Mission informed me that the school building is quite inadequate and should be replaced as soon as possible. After checking the building carefully I concur in this view. The building presents a real fire hazard. The foundation is decayed and heaved. The class rooms are small and unhealthy. It is therefore recommended that the replacement of this building be an item on the Educational Building Program for the Northwest Territories.

I encountered considerable criticism of the school on the part of residents of the Settlement. Many complained that the children were not learning very much by attendance. While such statements are not uncommon wherever a school is functioning, I do feel that a good deal of such criticism could be mitigated by making the instruction in each class more practical and vocational. For example, the instructional program in every school ought to include some training in sewing, home economics, woodworking, leather craft, motor mechanics and machine shop practice. I have endeavoured to make an immediate start in this direction, and instructions have been issued to Mr. L.E. Drummond, Departmental Agent, to send forward to the various Residential schools in the Territories a bundle of mixed woods together with a kit of tools to be used in working same.

The members of the teaching staff are as follows:

Sister Edna Gagnon - holds a Model Diploma for the Province of Quebec, and has 18 years teaching experience. She teaches Grades 1 to 8, and has 23 Residential pupils and 18 Day school pupils, making a total enrolment of 41. Attendance at the time of the visit was 23, most of whom were beginners. The teacher is conscientious and interested in her work. The reading is very good, the writing is excellent, and the pupils are making good progress in their number work.

Sister Marguerite Bourlai - holds no teaching certificate but has fifteen years experience. She teaches Grades 1 and 2,
has 25 Residential pupils and 16 day school pupils, making a total enrolment of 41. There were 29 pupils in attendance at the time of the visit. I examined some of the hand work being done by the pupils, listened to their reading, and enjoyed the singing.

Sister Oliva Lavoie - holds a second class permanent Alberta Certificate and has taught for 19 years. She has Grades 1 to 7. The total pupilage is 125, made up of 78 Residential and 47 day school pupils. The school is equipped with a silent film projector. It does not receive Radio Broadcasts. The children received a medical examination and are X-rayed for T.B. on their arrival at school. They also received Dental and Eye examinations. This teacher is very industrious. The children's notebooks were exceptionally good.

The teachers in the Territories quite understandably are not familiar with the enterprize method of education now being used so successfully in the Provinces. Its most valuable feature is that it encourages and trains the children in self expression. On subsequent visits I hope that there will be an opportunity to discuss this method fully with the teachers at the various settlements.

I would suggest that this school be furnished with a good set of Basic Readers. These are required in order that the native children may learn to read by the use of the most modern technique. The teachers have requested readers, knitting wool, prints for making aprons and dresses, and a sound film projector.

The teachers at these schools complain of the poor attendance and feel that some measures should be taken to remedy the condition. They feel that some authority other than the church should impress upon the parents the importance of sending a child to school. The teachers feel that school attendance is an important means of fighting the spread of T.B. They say housing conditions are very poor and that in many cases families are living on a starvation level.

J. W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

Education

The great majority of Treaty Indian children who go to school attend St. Joseph's Residential School in Fort Resolution. A handful are to be educated at the new school in Hay River but none attend school at Yellowknife.

Residential school is the most effective means at our disposal to improve the health of the children. They can be assured of adequate diet and complete medical care. All new pupils on entering the Fort Resolution school are given a complete medical check up, including X-Ray. They are inoculated against Diptheria and Whooping Cough and are vaccinated against Smallpox. Each fall this procedure is repeated as indicated. Each child is examined at monthly intervals by a hospital nurse and any lack of progress, for example, if there is no gain in weight, is brought to the attention of the Medical Superintendent and appropriate steps are taken.

The school building in Fort Resolution is outdated, dilapidated and a potential fire hazard. But the school, being filled with pupils, is serving its purpose. The building, however, should be replaced as soon as possible.

Day schools would be feasible propositions in Fort Resolution and Hay River. A day school in Fort Resolution would take some of the burden off the residential school and allow it to function far better in its capacity as a boarding school. A day school does not afford provisions for proper medical care of the pupils. Their segregation from open cases of Tuberculosis cannot be assured, and even if free from disease on admission, can contact Tuberculosis at any time. There can be very little control over their hygiene and none at all over their diet. In my opinion the outstanding need for a school is to assist in raising the health standards of the children and a day school cannot do this. These points apply particularly to Fort Rae where a residential school is badly needed.

Game Regulations and the Indians

If the caribou are becoming so scarce that they cannot be used in Indian hospitals and schools, why can any white man obtain a license to kill five animals a year? Why should Mr. Leo Lirette of Fort Resolution, who is a hotel and restaurant keeper, a trucker and a mink farmer, be allowed to kill as many caribou as he wishes and one of the brothers on the Mission staff, who like Mr. Lirette...
has a trapping license, was told that he could kill only five and must eat them all himself? Why should I, or any of the white population be allowed to buy caribou meat while the Mission cannot buy caribou meat to serve to the Indian patients who do not like beef? The Mission would be willing to buy their caribou meat and the purchase of this would mean a slight addition to the income of the Indians of this area.

Malnutrition is a welfare problem; if the Indians depended more on their original diet, the state of their nutrition should improve. One person died this winter from Beri-Beri. There are not a few cases of minimal scurvy, more noticeable at this time of the year.

The population of Fort Resolution consists of 12 white families, about 200 Half-breeds, the Mission personnel and D.O.T. employees. It is the headquarters for 48 Indian families, all Chipewyans, totalling 116 people.

Due to a complete lack of recreational facilities and to the Indian disinclination to discipline children, there is a high rate of juvenile delinquency. Since the young adults lack financial security there are few marriages and many illegitimate births.

The future for a young man growing up in Fort Resolution is uncertain. The building of a community hall would help to solve the recreational problem and a small sawmill might, by increasing employment, raise the standard of living.

The capacity of the Fort Resolution hospital will be doubled by this autumn; for this reason the Medical Superintendent of this agency will have to maintain his headquarters in this settlement.

Cher Seigneur et Excellence,

Les écoles d'Aklavik de Fort Résolution et de Providence ont chacune droit pour l'année courante, c'est-à-dire de janvier à la fin décembre 1948 à une augmentation de $30,00 par enfant. Celle de Chipewyan est de $20,05. Mais, on a mis à l'obtention de cette augmentation une condition que votre économie n'a pas encore remplie. Il faut que les livres de comptes des écoles soient vérifiés par un comptable du Département. Il semble bien entendu que si vous ne consentez pas à vous soumettre à cette exigence, on ne paiera pas l'augmentation. Comme il s'agit dans l'occurrence d'une somme de plus de $7,000,00, vous voudrez peut-être prendre les moyens nécessaires pour obtenir une aide si précieuse. Un autre point de vue qui devrait nous porter à accepter ce règlement du Département des Affaires Indiennes c'est que les écoles catholiques sont les seules qui ne s'y soient pas soumises.

Le frère Michel Dabrowski était de passage ici hier. Je l'ai accompagné au Département de l'Immigration pour obtenir une déclaration qui lui permettra de revenir au pays une fois que son voyage aura été terminé. Le Commissaire de l'Immigration lui a conseillé de ne pas aller en Pologne immédiatement, mais d'attendre plutôt l'année prochaine lorsqu'il aura obtenu son certificat de naturalisation, car il court bien des risques d'être retenu indéfiniment en Pologne. Je suis de l'avis du Commissaire et j'ai endossé le conseil qu'on lui avait donné. Il va donc retourner à Fort Résolution le plus tôt possible et attendre à l'année prochaine sinon à plus tard pour faire son voyage.

Affectueusement vôtre en N.-S. et M. I.

J.-O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the school term I believe it worthwhile to report on my observations at each point.

On September 12th, I flew with C.P.Airlines from Yellowknife to Fort Resolution. I visited the Residential School and they seemed to be anxious to do as much for the children as was possible. I had only visited the school once before just before the close of the term and I am not able to say whether there is any change in routine carried out or not. The principal of this school has just taken over, having been at Aklavik for some time. This Sister seemed very anxious to get additional equipment for certain types of Vocational training.

A request was received for three sewing machines and two typewriters. This request is being forwarded on a requisition form attached to this report.

A check was made of Attendance returns and Applications for Admission to school. These will be going forward at the end of the month as it has been found that the Indian children, as a rule, return during almost any period of this month and it was felt that it would be better to send all applications in at one time.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last term and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

(Sgd.) I.F.Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies

Re: Fort Resolution Indian Residential School. Your File 139-6-1

We are in receipt of your letter of September 27th in which you refer to your recent visit to the above mentioned school.

While we are quite prepared to supply the sewing machines to the school, it is our understanding that the machines could not be shipped to Fort Resolution until the opening of navigation next year. It is not our practice to forward such supplies by air.

We are prepared to order one typewriter for use at this school if you will let us know the length of the carriage. In supplying this machine we will also have to delay delivery until 1950.

Please let us hear further from you.

October, 22nd. 1949.

Mr. B.F. Neary
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re; Ft. Resolution Indian Residential School. Your file 916-5 (B1)

Further to my letter of Sept. 27th, the mission school have indicated that they would like a typewriter with a long carriage of 18" if possible. This seems long to me for the type of work that should be undertaken for the training of typists in this country. At the present time I am using a 13" carriage Remington typewriter in my office and have found it adequate for all my work. The long carriage typewriter is heavy to operate and for training I would favor the 15".

On my requisition sheet for both sewings and the typewriter I had given the date required as June 1st. 1950, it being my intention that the shipment should be in Waterways Alberta on that date for shipment via. N.T.C.L. during the first of the season when shipments are easier to route into places like Resolution which, though on the lake are a few miles off the down river route, and boats do not like to stop unless they have full loads.

It is very desirable to have shipments at Waterways early otherwise we are often forced to make special trips to out-of-the-way places and can have costly delays as we had at Ft. Rae this past summer.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Honourable Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favor No.46/G dated IO of June and I take advantage of this opportunity to present you with a new request in favor of our school at Providence.

The grant $200. a year the government is giving us for a day school is far from being even sufficient for the living of the devoted sisters. On account of the wandering life of all the Indians, we are obliged to keep their children in a school, to lodge, to board and clothe them the whole year. Some are coming from a very great distance, even from Good Hope and Peel River. At the present time there are over sixty children in that school.

It is the first school established in the north, some forty years ago. Then the reindeer, covering the whole country, were largely providing for the greatest part of the food necessary for so many mouths. Now, for many years, they have been keeping far away in the north and east. The only food to be found all around, besides a few vegetables, is fish, often poor, when eatable at all, for we have to keep it from September to the end of July. The freight on provisions from outside is too high for our means.

It would seem but right if the Government would take a step to improve the situation of that well deserving school.

Memorandum: Mr. Pedley,

With reference to the school at Providence, which I visited in the summer of 1902, I may say that I found it to be a very efficient boarding school. It was established many years ago by the Roman Catholic mission. The buildings are beautifully situated on the banks of the McKenzie river. While there Bishop Brezant asked me to visit the school and wanted me to recommend it to the Department for assistance, as they had about 70 pupils in attendance. I remember accurately telling the Bishop that as the school was outside treaty limits I could not see what could be done in the way of obtaining assistance; but told him he might write to the Commissioner and find out what could be done. As for the work done I do not think there is a better or more efficient school in the district.

Last when at Wabuscaw I visited the school at that place and found that a new building had been erected for the purposes of a convent, with a staff of four Sisters as teachers. The building is very well arranged for boarding school purposes. They had at the time of my visit about 35 treaty children attending. This school is apparently doing good work, and it is well situated.

As for the day school at Sturgeon Lake, no building had been put up when I was there last summer.
but Bishop Guirard told me he contemplated building this last summer, and I have no doubt he has done so.

I have my doubts as to the efficiency of a day school, as the Indians, in my opinion, do not take the same interest in sending their children to a day school as they do in sending them to a boarding school; and I am told by the traders and others living in the country that the Indian children will not attend regularly. When their parents take a notion to break camp they take all their family with them.

Inspector, Treaty 8.
It is stated that a number of the Treaty Indians attend the school at Providence. Is this the case, and if so, how many? How far from here is the nearest school house in existence? And how far are any Treaty Indians suffering from lack of school facilities near this place in regard to this?
Sir:

In reference to your memorandum asking how many Treaty Indian children were attending the school at Providence, I beg to say that there were none that I know of. I do not remember being told by Bishop Breazant how many, or if any.

The distance from Hay River to Providence is about 120 miles. Hay River has a good boarding-school run by the Anglican Church Mission Society. Last summer when at Resolution the R.C. Mission was building a convent for the purpose of a boarding-school with a staff of five Sisters, and I have no doubt that this school is now doing good work.

The distance from Resolution to Providence is 250 miles or thereabouts. This school is pretty central, as the Indians, as a rule, all trade at Resolution, in fact some from beyond the treaty limit come there to trade.

PROVIDENCE BOARDING SCHOOL (Roman Catholic)

No change has been made in the school buildings during the past year. It is proposed in the near future to raise the entire main building one storey and add a wing to the building on the east side.

The system of ventilation is very complete and the heating system by furnace in the basement. Water is supplied to the school by force pump from the Mackenzie river.

I was not able to attend the usual classes at this school but the children appeared to be particularly bright and clean. Facilities are provided for swimming and bathing in the summer time, a large swimming shed being erected on the shore of the river.

The health of the pupils has been good for the past year, but at the time of my visit an epidemic of grippe had been running through the school and many of the children had contracted this in a mild form.

Three children had been transferred from Fort Good Hope to the school in the spring by an order of the Indian agent at Simpson without having the necessary health certificate, the plea being put forward that they were orphans and had to be provided for in some way.

All of these children developed sickness after being at the school a short time and in consequence two of them died just prior to my arrival.

I would suggest that the regulation covering the admission of children to these boarding schools should be more rigidly enforced.

Sgd. H. J. Bury.

Mr. Scott.

Referring to the correspondence submitted by the Secretary of the Northwest Territories regarding the request made by Bishop Breynat of the Diocese of Mackenzie River that a grant be provided for the education of half-breed children, whom the Bishop states are in attendance in the Indian Schools, I beg to say that we have the following Indian Schools in operation in that territory, under the auspices of the Catholic Church, viz: -

Ft. Resolution Big. - Grant for 60 pupils at $145 P.C.,
Ft. Providence - " " 65 " " $145 P.C.,
Ft. Smith Day - Salary $900,
Ft. Simpson Day - " " $800.

Besides the above, there is a grant provided for 25 pupils at $145 per capita at Fort McMurray. No returns have yet been received from this point.

The day school at Fort Smith has been closed since June 30, 1920. The Agent states there is practically no Indian children to attend.

The returns which we receive from these schools contain the names of the children of Indian parents only. Frequently returns showing attendance of half-breed children are sent us, but they are immediately forwarded to Mr. George D. Pope, Controller of Northwest Territories. I called up Mr. Pope's office today and they tell me that they also receive returns showing attendance of half-breed children at schools in the Territories and that they pay grant for such schools. They send their cheques to Rev. Father Lefebvre, who is the treasurer of the Diocese, and to whom all grants for our Indian Schools are also sent.

The education of half-breed children does not come under the jurisdiction of our Department, unless, under a ruling of the Department, they reside on an Indian Reserve and live the Indian mode of life thereon.

Mr. Agent Card reports that at the time treaty was made these people were given the option of either taking script or treaty. Some took script and these are the children from the class to which the Bishop refers. This Department is not under any obligation to those who did not accept treaty, and is not responsible for their education.

I think the question of the education of half-breeds in the Northwest Territories is a matter for the Department of the Interior, Northwest Territories Branch, to deal with. We have no funds provided for the purpose.

PB CALGARY, ALTA., August 13th, 1936.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on the R. C. boarding school at Fort Providence.

This building was erected in 1930. The main part of the building is three stories high, and the wings two stories. This building is steam heated, and has hot and cold water.

At the time of my visit of course they were not holding classes, but most of the children were still in residence as very few go out for holidays. There were 40 girls and 30 boys present. The children put on a little concert in my honour, and I must say they did very well.

I was pleased to note that the children all looked well and happy, and a great deal different from those I saw around the different camps visited in my travels.

The fathers operate a small farm in connection with the school, where they raise a little grain. They have two horses, and also raise chickens. They maintain a good garden, although it did not look so promising owing to the lack of rain.

As far as I could see this school seems to be doing splendid work, as no doubt it gives both the boys and girls a better opportunity to attain a good standard of health.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,

At the time of my visit of course they were not holding classes, but most of the children were still in residence as very few go out for holidays. There were 40 girls and 30 boys present. The children put on a little concert in my honour, and I must say they did very well.

I was pleased to note that the children all looked well and happy, and a great deal different from those I saw around the different camps visited in my travels.

The fathers operate a small farm in connection with the school, where they raise a little grain. They have two horses, and also raise chickens. They maintain a good garden, although it did not look so promising owing to the lack of rain.

As far as I could see this school seems to be doing splendid work, as no doubt it gives both the boys and girls a better opportunity to attain a good standard of health.

Dear Sir:

I have just received a very distressing letter from Rev. Father Michel, who is in charge of the Fort Providence Catholic Mission and Indian Residential School.

You are aware that this School is authorized to receive 100 pupils. Last year its enrolment was never over 65 and this year there are only 45 pupils enrolled. General conditions being as they are, you will readily understand that it is well-nigh impossible for the School authorities to carry on with such a reduced pupilage. I am informed that everything has been done by the missionaries to bolster the attendance, but without substantial results. In order to bring the attendance to normalcy, it would seem recourse must be had to compulsion.

The Indian Act provides for compulsory attendance of Indian children either in Residential or Day Schools. To allow these children to roam the wilderness with their parents, is contrary to the spirit of the Act, and if this practice were allowed to take root, untold harm would likely be the result.

As I see it, there are three agencies that should take particular interest in the school attendance of our Indian children, the Mounted Police, the Indian Affairs Branch, through its Agents and the Church authorities in charge of each particular school. In the case of Fort Providence it appears that there has not been sufficient cooperation between these agencies with the result mentioned above. Would it not be possible to induce the Agent to use his influence to the utmost in a matter of this importance. Would it not be possible also for the Mounted Police to cooperate with the Indian Agent without, as far as possible, it being known that the Police is acting on orders from your Agent or from the School Principal.
If the above course were followed, it is likely that, as far as Fort Providence is concerned, the attendance would again reach its normal figure and the School would be in a position to carry out the work that it has done so successfully since its establishment.

There is one category of children whose attendance at School is imperative. I refer to orphans and abandoned children. At the present time these unfortunate waifs wander from one camp to another eking out a most miserable existence. Their place until at least they are 14 or 15 years of age, is in a Residential School.

I appeal to you in a very special manner for this Northern School. I hope that you will take immediate steps to increase its attendance, and especially to do all you can to place within its walls all the orphans and derelict children of the district.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

With regard to your letter of December 17, file 139-3-1, re Indian children attending Fort Providence Indian Residential School, let me say that I am glad that this matter has come up, and we will now be able to control the attendance of the Indian pupils at the Providence School.

In the past the Bishop always brought a number of children from the Providence School to Fort Simpson and Fort Wrigley to visit with their parents while the Bishop's boat went on down river to Aklavik, and they were supposed to go back with him on his return to Fort Providence School. However, a number always persuaded their parents to keep them with them rather than send them back to school, and there was always a small loss of pupils to the school in this way, who had not completed their education at the school. This usually happened when I was away on my treaty trips, and happened year after year, so that a number of pupils were missing from the school each year. The same situation prevails at Providence where the Sister in Charge allows the pupils to live with their parents for a few weeks each Summer on their promise to return to school on its reopening in the Fall. As a result a number of pupils have got back into the bush with their parents too far away to be compelled to return.

I am sure that with the co-operation of the police we will now be able to keep a full attendance of pupils at the school, and I am writing to the Corporal in charge at Fort Providence, asking him to see that all pupils are returned to the school by their parents in time for the Fall re-opening. I am following the same procedure in Fort Simpson and will proceed along the same lines, wherever families have sent their children to Fort Providence School. In future, I do not expect any difficulty in keeping the attendance at school up to its full quota.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

Research for Missing Children - Residential School, Providence, N.S.T.

1. It was brought to the attention of this detachment in the early part of the 29-7-42 that three brothers (ages from 5 to 9 yrs.) had run away from the local residential school and could not be located by the school and mission staff assisted by older children and a few local residents, as well as the shore being patrolled in canoes by Capt. Bouvier, Theodore Bouvier and Rev. Father Litz.

2. A more extensive search was therefore organized and Capt. Temple, in company with Lieut. Bouvier and his son traveled down stream, later followed by others with private cars, motors and canoes, as two Indians coming to the Fort reported that they had seen three objects, thought to be children, on the river bank in the distance, but had disappeared at their approach. Members went ashore and spread out along the bank, and the children were finally sighted by Capt. Temple who circled and approached them in long grass near a sandy island, approximately 6 miles from Providence, waiting there with them a short while until other parties arrived, when they were taken back by canoe and returned to the mission approximately 10:30 p.m.

3. Rev. Father Michel, in charge of the Mission, advises that these boys i.e., Isidore 5 yrs., Alfred 7 yrs., and Napoleon 9 yrs., are sons of MacDonald, halfbreeds, married to an Indian, and recently convicted and serving sentence for non-support at Norman, N.B. The three boys, with 2 younger children of the same family, were brought to Providence 29-7-42 to be kept at the school, with the understanding that the father pays the school $1.00 per child per month. The children, not realizing the distance, decided to run away and walk home; it is understood they made a previous attempt while enroute here.

4. Parties using private motors and canoes were reimbursed gasoline and oil by local purchase from the H.C.O., on order from this detachment. Certified account dated 1-8-42, to amount of $9.20, is being forwarded herewith in quadruplicate, and made chargeable to the Dept. of Mines & Resources. No other expense was incurred, and it is respectfully requested the account be approved.

5. As no further action appears necessary by this detachment the matter is being considered concluded.

Concluded.

Expenditure - Departmental expenditures up to 31st March, 1937, pertaining directly to preliminary investigations, the establishment and maintenance of the Reindeer Station and the purchase of the original reindeer stock from Alaska amounted in round figures to $350,000. Since that time the yearly cost of maintenance has averaged about $21,000. The following are the official figures for the past four years:

Revenue - Departmental receipts in respect of the reindeer industry consist of the proceeds of meat and hides sold from the main herd. These are surplus products after providing for direct relief, donations to missions and meat for the local mission, offices and camp purposes. The funds are used to provide for the division native and white, who are in a position to pay for these products. The proceeds of meat disposed of in lieu of wages are included in the sales. Utilization of Reindeer Products - The original stock of 2,370 reindeer from Alaska delivered to the Canadian range east of the Mackenzie delta in March, 1935, had increased by the summer of 1943 to more than 9,000 head, in three herds - 6,570 deer in the main herd on the reserve and 3,174 animals in two herds under native management near the Anderson and Horton Rivers. During the development of the reindeer herds, meat and hides are provided for the use of those directly engaged or connected with the herding work. In addition meat is available for direct relief and large quantities are supplied each year to the mission hospitals and residential schools in the Akivik area as a contribution toward the maintenance of these institutions. For the benefit of the natives, more than $20,000 carcasses from the main herd have been supplied free to the missions. These represent a value at local prices of about $23,000. The hides are used for local purposes with a number of surplus hides being made available for shipment to needy Eskimos in the Eastern Arctic.

In the case of native herds the natives in charge are allowed to take meat, hides, sinews, etc., from surplus stock for their own use or to sell or exchange for necessary cash, furs, supplies or services. Any cases of destitution in the vicinity of the herds are to be supplied with reindeer products on a basis of replacement from the main herd.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am very, very grateful to you for your kindness in returning the September Quarterly Returns for revision.

May I call your attention to the fact that the School Calendar in the Indian Bulletin had set the 25th of June as the last day of the school year 1947-48 and we were to re-open on September 7th, which we did.

On the Returns for the June Quarter I cancelled the number of days pupils were absent from the school in June. The majority of the pupils left for vacation on the 25th of June.

In the case of Patrice Nadli, No. 248 instead of 91 days in June Quarter, he was entitled to 86. In this Quarter he is entitled to 62 days holiday plus 17 days in September, as he returned on September 14th, thus 79 days in the Quarter. I did likewise with all the other pupils.
The note I had put opposite his name on the Return was not meant for him. It was to notify that the class rooms had been closed for four days to take in the crops.

Trusting you find the Returns satisfactory and I wish to thank you once again, Mr. Phelan.

Yours most sincerely,

Sister Mary Mack, s.g.m.
