4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Register, ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Extract from Report of Inspector H.A.Conroy on the Boarding schools in Treaty No. 8 and Mackenzie District. Dated December 18/11. Original on File 160370-18E

PROVIDENCE...

The most northerly school in the Mackenzie District is the one under the Roman Catholic Church, at Providence.

The foundations are blocks of wood. The walls are logs, covered on the outside with tar paper and planks. Their thickness is about ten inches.

There is a new wing under construction which will add greatly to the school. It will be a three story addition 30 x 30, and will contain several class rooms and dormitories.

The accommodation at present is just about sufficient for the grant from the Department. There are five large dormitories, whose cubic space is 27,246 cubic feet, sufficient for 64 pupils. The class rooms, three in number, whose floor space is sufficient for over one hundred pupils, but whose cubic space, 15,375 feet, accommodates only 61.

A small dormitory is kept ready for cases of sickness.

The foundations of the main buildings are blocks of wood; the walls are logs covered outside with tar paper and planks, bringing them up to 10" thickness. The lighting and ventilation are good.

From both the boys and girls dormitories there are outside staircases in case of fire. In almost all the missions economy of space has been detrimented to the inside...
Providence cont.

stairways, and there should be at least a ladder from dormitory windows in case of emergency. There are no fire extinguishers at Providence, but pails are kept ready. I would recommend that the Department send in some fire extinguishers.

The water supply is obtained from the river. The Mission is situated some 30 or 90 feet above the water. A small tramway is built to the water's edge to overcome the difficulty of hauling pails of water up a very steep bank. A force pump is also in use during the summer. The water is stored in barrels near the kitchen, and distributed throughout the building in pails. If the Department could see their way clear to send in some sheets of galvanized iron, the mission would construct a tank that would give water to the whole building.

There is no furnace; six stoves are used which seem to give satisfaction.

The class work follows the requirements of the Department. Besides this, the boys are taught the use of axe and saw, and the girls receive instruction in cooking and sewing. General manual training has been found unpractical in this district. General use of ordinary tools however, is essential, and it is dealt with in every boarding school. I would recommend that the Department send in a couple of blackboards, wall maps of Canada and the North, a globe, a few desks, some slates and a couple of bathtubs. The last are a decided necessity in any school.

The mission owns 28 head of cattle. They are in danger, however, of becoming inbred, and I would strongly recommend that when cattle are sent to Fort Simpson, the Providence Mission be allowed the use of a bull for at least a season.
Providence concluded

The garden for so northerly a district, is exceptionally fine. Experiments are being carried on with different seeds and flowers. The Mission raises from 1,200 to 1,500 barrels of potatoes every year; besides vegetables of various kinds, and some grain used for the cattle. I would suggest that if possible, the Department send in a hundred pounds of chemical fertilizer to assist in the experimental work so ably carried on.

Sgd. H.A. Conroy,

Inspector Treaty No.8

Dear Father Guy:

I wish to refer to your letter of the 16th ultimo, requesting that the Deputy Superintendent General favourably consider the purchase of a threshing machine and a wind-mill for the Fort Providence Indian Boarding School.

In reply I beg to state that the Estimates for the coming fiscal year are now in the hands of the Treasury Board, and it was too late to incorporate an item with reference to the demands of His Lordship Bishop Breynat. The vouchers should be properly certified by himself, when the machine is placed in the car at Montreal, and should be forwarded to Ottawa for payment.

Dear Mr. Scott:

For the last few years I have been advocating the reconstruction of our Indian Boarding School at Providence, and have consequently made formal requests to the Department. The latter has not seemed to be favorable to such requests as no action has followed.

The time has come, in my humble opinion, for the Department to determine a policy concerning educational problems in favor of the Indians of the North West Territories. I must say immediately that the very large majority of those Indians are Catholics, and, therefore under my spiritual jurisdiction. I necessarily have their interests at heart and would be grateful to the Department for assisting us more intensively in the work we have been carrying on in the North for the last 75 years.

After mature consideration of present conditions and requirements I take the liberty of making a proposal to the Department for the construction of a new school at some point in the lower McKenzie. Presently, some children have to go about 900 miles up the McKenzie to attend school, which is almost incredible. It is a known fact that the Indians of the lower McKenzie are far more intelligent than those of the upper portion and a school in that district would certainly be a boon (not to say an absolute necessity) to the Hare Skins, the Loucheux and occasionally to the Eskimos.

Therefore, instead of asking for the reconstruction of Providence School at the Government's expense I hereby request a grant of about $30,000.00 for the construction in the Lower McKenzie District, of a boarding school to accommodate about 30 children. The condition would be that full liberty be given me for the construction of said school. The Department is conversant with the fact that in the N.W.T. on account of difficul-
ties of transportation there would be no possibility of constructing such a building at a reasonable price if the procedure (calling for tenders, etc.) is followed. Our experience in construction, the number of expert carpenters and mechanics at our disposal would highly facilitate the work, bring the expense to a minimum and guarantee perfect work. I would therefore be prepared for the sum above mentioned ($30,000.00) to erect a school according to the plans and specifications of the Departmental architect, to accommodate 30 children. Such plans and specifications could be prepared with a view of extending the building at a later date. All accounts for material, freight and work would be submitted to the Department and work would be considered satisfactory only after an inspection from an Officer of the Department. Said construction could be started and completed in the course of next year.

Moreover, I would pledge myself to erect in a very few years, at my own expense, another school at Providence. The Department authorities must admit that I am more than reasonable in my requests and generous in my promises. As practically nothing has been done (outside of the per capita grant) in favor of the education of our Indian children of the N.W.T. I am positive that the Government will look favorably upon my present proposition.

Thanking you for your personal interest in this matter, I remain,

Yours very truly,

PROVIDENCE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

At Providence Boarding School they had an outbreak of typhoid this fall, as reported previously, in September, but as it was impossible for me at that time to procure the lease of a boat (being all engaged in fishing for the winter) I could not go at that time and attend to these cases. Five of the children died, and a few of the convalescents are so badly affected that their complete recovery is problematic.

I examined the buildings and surroundings to discover the probable cause of the typhoid being more or less endemic in that locality. There is not apparently one cause alone but a few defects here and there in drainage and surface water which give very much trouble and are without doubt causing the sickness, although all the first cases are always some children coming from the lower part of the MacKenzie, starting the epidemic. We have advised correcting all the possible dangers and risks of further outbreak. The buildings are getting old and it is very difficult for the buildings to have any cellars as the water penetrates in spite of all kinds of devices and will stay in these cellars until pumped out.

INDIAN AGENT, RESOLUTION, N.W.T., Dated Feb. 12, 1924.

PROVIDENCE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

At Providence I was greatly impressed with their success in raising poultry and their supply of fresh eggs this winter with good healthy hens shows the possibilities that can be encouraged in this country. They have at the R.C. Mission at this time over one hundred and fifty hens, getting now three dozen eggs daily. Last summer the number of chickens reached four hundred. As their land is not yet cleared sufficiently large enough to raise all feed for these hens, they will have to import from outside about twenty-four bags of wheat for next winter. I promised to ask the Department for help in obtaining this wheat shipped from Edmonton, in order to encourage the other institutions to raise more poultry, and when the Indians around the Forts see this success, they may have a tendency to clear a small tract of land to do the same, in time.
PROVIDENCE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

At Providence I examined the school children and was astonished with their progress and talents in various subjects - English and French languages; sewing and knitting, etc., all these practical subjects being also of great value to these children. Especially the industry of socks knitting I would like to encourage as much as possible in young girls, but the knitting wool is beyond reach of the average purse in the Indians as it costs from eight dollars a pound to ten. With your approval I would ask a little supply next year in the Estimates to develop this work by the women.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Before leaving definitely for my remote mission field I feel in duty bound to renew my thanks for the very kind attention shown to me whilst in Ottawa.

Acting upon your suggestion in the matter of the reconstruction of our Residential School at Providence, I am presently bringing the case officially before the Department.

You are aware that Providence School is the first Indian Residential School built in the North and has been the only one for a rather long time. In fact, we are celebrating this very year, in our humble sphere, a jubilee coinciding with that of our dear Dominion: a diamond jubilee.

During the sixty years of its existence I can state that this institution has wrought wonders for our Northern population and has shown the way to establishments of a similar nature. It will of interest for you to note that we have never received nor asked for help in the way of capital expenditure for our institutions of the North West Territories which, outside of day-schools at almost every mission point, include three residential schools and three hospitals. I may add that for forty years we have not received the least grant for our children, a small salary of $300 to $400 being given after many years to one teaching sister.

Our residential school at Providence, after sixty years of wear and tear, has come to the point where repairs and alterations are an utter impossibility. We are thinking upon the erection of a new and modern building. As we realize that the Department would probably not consider the construction of such a building at its own expense in so remote a country we are ready to assume the cost of said construction but feel the the Department should favor
us with a very substantial grant, same to be fixed after discussion with myself or my representative.

I hope that my request will be found in order and most opportune at this juncture. I therefore leave the whole matter to your kind attention and judicious consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Bishop of [Name]

Fort McMurray September 21 1927.

To D.C. Scott Esq.
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Department of the Interior, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your kind letter of July the 8th, No. 129-3-5, I beg to explain that before completing our plans for the reconstruction of our Providence Indian Residential school we are awaiting to know what financial help we may expect from the generosity of your Department.

We are contemplating the building of a school as modern in its plan as the conditions in the North will permit, cement basement included. On account of the high rate of freight for the necessary material as well as of the high wages generally asked in the North, I am figuring that the total amount of expenses for the building would run between fifty or sixty thousand dollars. Would it be exaggerated to expect from the Department a financial help large enough to cover half of that amount?

I may state again that so far, we never have received any help from the Department for any of the five large establishments we actually possess, in the District of Mackenzie. In particular our Providence school which was established the very year of the Confederation, not only has been, as others, created at our own expenses, but it has been kept working and doing good work for the period of nearly forty years, without any grant from the Department.

With the hope of an early favorable reply to our demand,

I remain,

with anticipations,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

MEMO FOR FILE:

His Lordship Bishop Breynat visited the Department this morning and explained their programme and wishes in connection with the reconstruction of the Providence Indian Residential School. This past summer, a good-sized barn with galvanized iron roofing was erected. Next year, they hope to purchase and freight in most of the material required for the new main building, and by the fall they expect to have the foundation ready. The expense next year will be $25,000 or $30,000. His Lordship is asking the Department to meet half the expense, and I have noted, for the attention of the Hon. Mr. Stewart and Dr. Scott, an item of $15,000 for 1929-30 estimates. In the summer of 1930, His Lordship will make a special effort to complete the building, so that they can get in by November or December. He expects that the total cost will be approximately $60,000, and he is requesting that a second item of $15,000 be granted by the Department that year.

I presume you will be pleased to hear that we have begun our work of complete reconstruction of our Providence School.

As was intended, we are first replacing the outbuildings. The new barn is nearly completed, the measurements of which are 75'x 34', and is covered with galvanized iron as a fire protection.

We now have to gather as much material as possible in order to proceed towards the erection of the main building according to the plans so kindly supplied by your Department. We hope to have everything on hand before the close of the navigation season this summer. By that time the cement foundations we expect, will be completed and we will then be able to resume and continue our work as long as the weather will permit.

As we cannot afford to borrow all the money from a Bank at the prevailing high rate of interest which would have to run for at least two years, I would appreciate it very much if you could advance us, out of the generous contribution you promised, the sum of Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00). We could then manage to wait for the balance of the grant until the construction is completed to the satisfaction of your Department.

Trusting that this request will meet your approval, I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Mr. Scott,

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that the main building at the Providence Indian Residential School, in the North West Territories, is more than sixty years old, and is now entirely unsuitable for the purposes of educating Indian children. The Oblate Order under whose auspices this school is conducted, has agreed to erect a new school building, at an approximate cost of $60,000.00, provided the department will undertake one-half the expense.

An amount of $15,000.00 has been included in the Main Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1939/30, and it is proposed to include a similar amount in the Estimates for 1930/31, for this purpose.

Plans and specifications for the proposed building have been prepared by the department. Accommodation for eighty pupils is provided.

The building is to be of frame construction on a concrete foundation and heated by a low pressure steam system. A septic tank and sewerage system is to be installed and all modern plumbing fixtures throughout the building.

In the opinion of the Architect of the department the cost would probably exceed the sum of $60,000.00 by a considerable amount. It follows, therefore, that the proposed expenditure by the department of $30,000 does not represent more than one moiety of the total cost.

In view of the remote location of Providence, which is some seven hundred miles distant from the railway line at Waterways it would appear to be inexpedient to call for tenders. It is considered that the most economical way of having the building constructed is by lay labour under the supervision of the Church authorities, as they are in a position to provide economical labour and can handle the freighting of the materials required at minimum cost.
The undersigned has the honour to recommend that the proposed grant to be expended in the manner aforesaid be approved.

Dear and kind Sir:

I am very glad to tell you how happy I am to be in my nice new class-room; as I have been teaching in it since about two months, I know by my own experience that it is ideal.

What a change, dear Sir, for both teacher and pupils to come from that old little church where I was teaching, and get in this new class-room where we have plenty of light and good fresh air. More than ever, since I am here, I incite my pupils to appreciate the unsurpassed devotedness of our dear benefactors, especially of those who co-operated in the construction of our new School, and you may trust that they understand it will ever be impossible for them to repay what they owe.

Next year, I intend to send you a few pieces of their class-works, if you just allow me to do so. You will then have a proof that they succeed quite well and really take advantage of their studies.

I may say I have all that I am in need of for my pupils and I am using everything as economically as possible. The only thing missing now is a teacher's desk and chair for each of the two classes. I wanted to show Mr. Parker the miserable old desks we have and unfortunately I did not see him, so I thought I would address myself directly to you, hoping you will be able to get it for us. I know it is an expensive furniture, but it lasts for years, and besides it adds to the appearance of the class.

I most deeply appreciate, dear and kind Sir, all you have done for me since I am in this School. Please accept my most sincere thanks and good wishes.

October 13, 1930

Mr. R.T. Ferrier,
Superintendent of the Indian Education Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I regret that the unexpected illness of Archbishop Grouard prevented me entertaining you during my last visit at Ottawa.

Regarding the construction of our Providence school, I am sending you presently the accounts of expenses up to August 2nd, which amount to $59,876.85. We have done our utmost to keep expenses low. I must remark that the digging of the sewers for the water system has been quite expensive on account of the very hard ground.

You will notice that the cost price of the heating system and its installation are not included in this account. It will be sent later on and I hope that the Government will come to our help to pay this extra amount. There is also about from $3000.00 to $4000.00 worth of inside finishing work to be done in order to complete everything.

In the meantime, if you find that the account are satisfactory, I would be grateful if you would send me as soon as possible to Father Lefebvre the balance of $5000.00 dol., which remains due as a part of the contribution of the Government. Times are so hard that the cheque would be all the more welcome.

Inspector Parker, having visited our school, will give you his appreciation of the work that has been done.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

We beg to submit the following proposal for installing and completing Plumbing System in Providence Indian Residential School, Fort Providence, N.W.T.

**SYSTEM**
The Plumbing to include a complete system of Hot and Cold Water Supply and drainage to the various fixtures throughout the building.

**FIXTURES**
One Only, one compartment steel kitchen sink with Nickle Taps and Trap complete.
Sixteen Only, Closet Combinations with oak tank and seat complete.
Three Only, 5' C.I. Porcelain Enamelled Bath with Nickle Plated Fittings.
Twenty Four Only, 17 x 19 C.I. Porcelain Enamelled R.R. Washbasins complete with 1½" Trap and Nickle Plated Compression Taps.
One Only, 188 Gallon Galvanized Range Boiler located in Boiler Room and connected to jacket Heater supplied and installed by this contractor.
One Only, 40 Gallon Range Boiler connected to Kitchen Range.
One Only, 1000 Gallon Steel Storage Tank complete with mountings, connected to Pump. Pump to be connected with Gasoline with Automatic Cut Off and to have a rated capacity of 1200 gallons per hour.

**GENERAL**
All the above equipment and fixtures together with all necessary pipe, fittings and labor including all drain piping to river and piping from the well to be supplied and everything left in first class working order and guaranteed to be satisfactory in every respect.

Hoping above price meets with your approval.

We beg to remain,

We beg to submit the following proposal for installing the complete One Pipe System of Steam Heating in the Providence Indian Residential School at Fort Providence, N.W.T.

**BOILER** The Steam Heating Boiler to be a Gurney Bright Idea Boiler with ample capacity based on wood for fuel, complete with firing tools and to comply with the Interprovincial Boiler Act.

**PIPING** All necessary pipe, fittings and hangers to be supplied and installed to make complete installation.

**COVERING** Cover steam mains in basement with Asbestos Air Cell Covering Branches to be left bare. Boiler to be covered with 1½" Asbestos Cement over wire lath, finished with cotton pasted on.

**SMOKE PIPE** Boiler to be connected to chimney with Galvanized Iron Smoke Stack 20" in diameter and made of 18" gauge iron.

**GENERAL** Above system to be installed complete and left in good working order and guaranteed to heat building to your satisfaction.

All carpenter work and cutting to be done by owner.

Mission St-Héodore, Fort Smith, December 10, 1930.

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Doctor:

I have regretted very much that the illness of Mr. Grouard forced me to leave Ottawa in a hurry, depriving me of the pleasure of the second visit to which you had kindly invited me.

Among the various affairs I intended to see you about, was the one of our Residential school at Providence. As usually happens, the building expenses have somewhat exceeded our estimates, the high transportation rates being the main cause to this. Besides, to have our school fitted with an up-to-date equipment which would be a real credit to both your Department and ourselves, we decided the installation of a steam heating plant with running water on all stories, to insure a better protection against fire danger.

When last May I had the honor to lay those plans before you, you were kind enough to invite me to send in a complete report, after the completion of the work, and you promised to do all in your power to have the supplementary contribution granted.

The building was sufficiently advanced this Fall to allow the children to move in; the news received lately show the contentment of all. The heating and water system is giving good satisfaction. The children are in the best of health.

As will be seen by the report already submitted, we had, to date, spent $60,000. And we have received with real gratitude the full amount of the agreed contribution.

Since then, a well was sunk; the first attempt was not successful; the water being unsatisfactory; and we had to use dynamite to dig another one. A large poultry-house, 75 x 16, has been completed. There's quite an amount of finishing work to do, inside.

The lighting and fire escape system has not been put up yet. The estimates for these we figure at about $3,000. I did not inquire about the prices, not having the means to procure them.

I inclose herewith a statement covering the cost and installation of the heating and water system.

To sum up, the supplementary expenses are as follows:

Inside finishing work & outbuildings XXXXX 3,000.-
Lighting plant, estimated 5,000.-
Heating and water plant 18,437.-

Inspector Parker visited the building when on his tour along the Mackenzie River, last Summer.

In the hope that you will find your way to help us meeting the above supplementary expenses, which are obviously necessary to complete the installation,

I remain, dear Doctor, Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Bishop of Athabasca
Vicar Apostolic

Dear Doctor:

I want to thank you very sincerely for your wire transmitting your kind greetings for Christmas season and best wishes for the new year.

I am pleased to tell you of my own, wishing you a real happy and prosperous new year.

I take pleasure also to enclose herewith some pictures of our new Residential School at Providence, with the poultry-house attached to it. The news lately received confirm our provisions that the heating system is giving good satisfaction, as also the water system. I am always confident that the Department will help defraying the cost.

Oct. 27th, 1933.

Dr. McGill,

Bishop Breynat, in the course of conversation with the Minister on Wednesday, asked that the Department pay a portion of the cost of the heating plant installed at the school or hospital at Fort Providence.

The Minister would like a report as to the Department's undertaking in the matter, if there is any.

Private Secretary.
November 1, 1933.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Referring to memorandum of the 27th ultimo, relative to the request of Bishop Breynat, in conversation with the Honourable the Minister, that the Department pay a portion of the cost of the heating plant installed at the Providence Mission Indian Residential School, I have to say:

In the summer of 1929, plans were prepared for a new school building, of frame construction, on a concrete foundation, to provide accommodation for 80 pupils. This building was to be heated by low pressure steam system and equipped with all modern plumbing fixtures and a septic tank as sewage system installed. Owing to the isolated location, the work was carried out by day labour, under the supervision of Bishop Breynat, as he was in a position to provide economical labour and handle the freighting of the materials required at a minimum cost. The minimum cost of the building was estimated at $75,000.

By P.C. 834, of the 30th of May, 1929, authority was given to pay the sum of $30,000 towards the cost - funds for the purpose having been provided as follows:

$15,000 in the Main Estimates for the year 1929-30
$15,000 " " " " " " " " " " " " 1930-31

Payment to the above amount was made, which, as stated in the order in Council referred to above, did not represent more than one moiety of the total cost.

In December, 1931, His Lordship requested a supplementary $10,000 towards the cost of installing the heating and water systems, and Dr. Scott, former Deputy Superintendent General, instructed that an item to this amount be provided in the supplementary Estimates for the year 1932-33. This item was, however, disallowed.

Bishop Breynat has already forwarded accounts, which are on file, covering the cost of the installation of the heating and water system, to a total amount of $16,437.23.

November 23, 1933.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

With reference to the enquiry of the Honourable the Minister, as to what understanding or agreement, if any, was entered into with Bishop Breynat to pay a portion of the cost of the heating plant installed at the Providence Mission Indian Residential School, I would say, as stated in my memorandum of the first instant, that the cost of the building was estimated at $75,000. The Department agreed to provide the sum of $30,000 towards the cost, and this amount has been paid. The plans for the building called for the installation of a steam heating plant, water system, and septic tank for sewage disposal. This was installed by the church authorities, at a cost of $15,437.

The only definite authority on file, promising to reimburse Bishop Breynat for this expenditure, is contained in a memorandum from Dr. Scott, former Deputy, addressed to Mr. Pageau, former Chief Accountant, requesting him to include in the Supplementary Estimates for 1931-32 an item of $15,000 towards the cost of the heating apparatus and water system at the school. His Lordship visited the Department from time to time, and the discussions regarding the matter were verbal between himself, Dr. Scott and the late Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education.

Besides installing the heating plant and the water system, the church authorities have installed a lighting plant, at a cost of, approximately, $5,000.

From the correspondence on file, I am unable to state, other than as mentioned above, what understanding or agreement was made to reimburse Bishop Breynat for the expenditure incurred by him in installing the heating and water systems.

Ottawa, July 26, 1934.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,-

The undersigned has the honour to report that Bishop Broynat installed, in the Providence Mission Indian Residential School, in the Northwest Territories, at a cost of, approximately, $15,000.00, a steam heating plant, water system and septic tank for sewage disposal.

An amount of $5,000.00 has been included in the Main Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, 1934-35, as a grant towards the cost of the above mentioned system.

In view of the remote location of the Providence Mission Residential School, it is considered that the installation of the heating plant, water system and septic tank under the supervision of the Church Authorities was the most economical way of having this work done.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that the proposed grant, to be expended in the manner aforesaid, be approved.

Dear Sister,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 19th ultimo, requesting certain equipment for the Providence Mission Indian Residential School. The articles that you mention are quite expensive and, in addition, there would be the transportation costs.

On the occasion of his next visit to your school, you should consult the Indian Agent with a view to ascertaining if some local carpenter could be obtained who would erect swings at a reasonable cost. The Department is prepared, if you so desire, to forward footballs and playground balls.

Your request for assistance for two ex-pupils should also be submitted to the Indian Agent. With regard to the suggestion that a sewing machine be supplied for one of the girls, reports reaching the Department indicate that, in many cases where sewing machines have been supplied, the recipients have not made proper use of them. Consequently, before considering the supplying of a sewing machine to any ex-pupil, the Department will require very definite assurance that the machine will be properly cared for by the recipient.

Kindergarten wool is not usually supplied to Indian residential schools.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Father Dobin, in charge of our residential school at Fort Providence has referred to me your circular letter in regard to precautions against fire.

I think that so far as this Juvenile School is concerned there is but little danger from furnaces or cookstoves. According to the plan which was submitted to the Department when the building was being erected two sets of stairs are provided and I think they answer the purpose for the number of pupils and the staff.

But there is a real danger of fire from the lighting system which consists of kerosene lamps. A large number of these is required owing to the size of the building and although great care is taken by the Sisters to watch, it is a real nightmare for us as some of the small children may play with them upset them or do something alike.

For the last two years I have insisted upon the Indian Department that an appropriation be granted for the installation of an electric lighting plant, so far the demand has received no favorable reply. The pupilage grant is too small to permit us to deduct the price of such a plant as it barely covers the maintenance of the pupils.

It is to be regretted that the Department takes on himself such a responsibility by overlooking the provision of this plant. Several visitors of the school were daily surprised of this dangerous kerosene lamp system and could hardly realize that the Government has declined to supply an electric plant.

May I hope, dear Sir, that the terrible accidents lately reported in the press will induce the Department to avoid any further delay and to provide funds for this lighting plant for the residential school of Fort Providence.

Trusting that this will be given the most favorable consideration, I remain, dear Sir,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir,

I have been directed by the Rt Reverend Bishop G. Breynat, who is actually visiting his missions up-North, to write you on his behalf regarding the lighting plant and electrical installation for the Indian Res. School at Fort-Providence, N.W.T.

In his letter to you of last April 15th, Bishop Breynat was asking that the allocations of $500. for Fort-Resolution school - general repairs-, also $500. for Fort-Providence school -general repairs-, and even the allocation of $300. for class-room material for Providence school, be allotted for the installation of this lighting plant. All of these allocations were mentioned in your letter of last April 4th.

When replying to Bishop Breynat, you agreed in your letter of the 22nd of April to his proposal, and in the last paragraph of this letter, you requested His Lordship to give you full details regarding other requisites required in connection with the installation of the lighting plant as soon as he would have received necessary informations from Providence.

These informations from Providence were received early this month. Then we had to give plans of the school to an electrician who is thoroughly acquainted with the various missions posts in the North, in order to have him figuring the material which would be necessary and to have quotations for same.

Quotations have been asked both from the Canadian General Electric Co., - from which firm you purchased the plant-, and from the Bruce-Robinson Electric Co., of Edmonton. It may be well to inform you that the quotation from the Can. General Electric amounts to $681.78, while the quotation from the Bruce-Robinson Electric amounts to $673.51 only, prices being quoted f.o.b. Waterways. These quotations have been given us on the 24th instant.

We know that your Department has decided that all purchases made by your purchasing Agent and we were ready to hand these quotations over to you. Nevertheless, you will
Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Dept of Mines & Resources........

undoubtedly realize our position in this occurrence for the following reasons:

The last boat leaving Ft-Smith for Providence is scheduled for August 20th, and freight for this boat should arrive at Waterways three weeks before the boat leaves Ft-Smith; otherwise, one is not entitled to have the freight going through from Waterways to Ft-Smith for sure. Then, if this material for Providence is not shipped from Edmonton at least by the train of August 2nd, it means that the installation would have to be postponed until next summer. And you are aware that we have only one train a week between Edmonton and Waterways.

Consequently, we could not help but giving immediately the order for the material to the Bruce-Robinson Electric Co., so that everything would be ready and crated carefully for shipment by the train of August 2nd. By waiting longer until we would get a definite reply from Ottawa, we would have simply lost all chance to have this material delivered at Providence this fall.

Along with the list of material needed for the installation, we have requested the electrician to give us an estimate of the price that he would charge us for the installing of everything. His prices are as follows:

| Item                          | Price   |
|-------------------------------|---------|
| Wiring                        | $336.75 |
| Installing of the plant        | $100.00 |
| Transportation of electrician  |         |
| from Edmonton to Providence & back | $200.00 |

Total $636.75

So, the total of both material and work will amount to $1,310.26

We have not included in this estimation the freight of the plant and material from Waterways to Providence, which would amount to some $400., to $450., nor the charges for boarding the electrician at Providence, nor any expenses in connection with the erection of the power house.

The electrician to whom we refer in this letter is Mr Stanley Sunley, electrical contractor of Edmonton, who has been making in the past our installations at the Indian School of Fort Resolution, at the Hospital of Fort Simpson and the Hospital of Ft-McMurray.
Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Dept of Mines & Resources........

His ability as well as his low prices are well known here. For reference, we might mention you that, among other contracts, he has awarded this year the contract for wiring the new store of the Hudson's Bay Company and the new hangar for the Trans-Canada Air Lines in Edmonton. We trust him as the most reliable man we could choose for doing our installations up-North and we always found his work highly recommendable.

Trusting all these informations will enable you to give a fair consideration to this matter,

I beg to remain,

Respectfully yours,

We were very disappointed in not receiving the order for the Plant at Providence, and in view of the fact that there was some difference in price I think that we should point out to you that the Plant which is being supplied at a lower price is not a direct-connected Plant or radiator cooled, and it is not being supplied with Ironclad Batteries.

The Plant being supplied is a belt driven Plant, is tank cooled, and is being supplied with a plated plate type of Battery.

We hope this piece of equipment arrives in good order, and we might say that we will have a man in Fort Smith early in August and he will inspect this machine and adjust it if it needs it.

acceptance of their tender.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Purchase of lighting system for Providence Mission Residential School

May I refer to my memorandum to you of October 15 and Mr. Jackson's reply thereto dated October 19, 1938?

In my memorandum of October 15, an attempt was made to summarize correspondence that had taken place between this Branch and your office, with respect to the purchase of a lighting plant for the Providence Mission Residential School. I felt that you should have before you this information when protests with respect to the delay in making this particular purchase reached you from the church authorities. I also felt that the Canadian General Electric Company should be called upon to replace the batteries next year. I had no thought in mind at that time of either attaching blame or focusing responsibility for the regrettable delay that has occurred. I realize that with central purchasing in force delays such as this, particularly in the early stages, are almost inevitable. There does not appear to be any dispute with respect to the procedure as outlined in my memorandum. Mr. Jackson does state, however, that our requisition did not give sufficient details. The officials inform me that this purchase was discussed on more than one occasion with His Lordship Bishop Breynat, who was of the opinion that the lighting system should be similar to the one supplied the Fort Resolution School in 1936. This plant, since the date of its installation, has given complete satisfaction.

May I refer, therefore, to the third paragraph of my memorandum -
memorandum to you dated May 5, 1938, copy of which I attach?

I feel that, in justice to the officials of the Training Division, I should refer to the paragraph in your memorandum in which you state: "Notwithstanding that the Company is to blame for delay in making shipment, the order should have been followed up by officials of your Branch and an endeavour made to secure early delivery".

I am enclosing herewith copy of a telegram dated Ottawa, July 7, 1938, prepared by the Chief of the Training Division, signed by myself and forwarded to Bishop Breynat. This telegram was prepared and sent forward just as soon as the Chief of the Training Division had secured, by phone, the necessary information from the Purchasing Agent.

I feel that Mr. Jackson, in making this comment, has overlooked the position in which the Chief of the Training Division found himself during the summer months. You may remember that from May 18 until August 3 Mr. Phelan was the sole official in the Training Division. During these months he was responsible for the preparation of our summer building programme, the repair of Indian day and residential schools, the engagement and re-engagement of teachers at the end of the academic year. In addition to this, he had to deal with thousands of applications for tuition grants during the month of July and had to prepare and send forward to the Purchasing Division all the memoranda relating to purchases in his Division. To ask a man placed in this position to follow up any particular order and see that delivery was made is asking, in my humble judgment, our officials to undertake and accomplish what is wholly impossible.

I have been informed that at no time during the conferences that have been held by the officials of our Branch with the Purchasing Agent has the suggestion been made that the officials of our Branch were responsible for the prompt delivery of the supplies. In this connection you will be interested to know that, when our officials did attempt to expedite the delivery of school desks at the Oneida School, the company responsible for delivery did not even have the courtesy to acknowledge receipt of our letter. In other words -
words, companies supplying orders received from the Purchasing Agent of the Department of Mines and Resources do not feel under any obligation to acknowledge receipt of letters from officials of the Indian Affairs Branch. I am of the opinion that to have the Purchasing Agent place the orders and have our officials communicate with the companies with respect to deliveries and time of deliveries will lead in the end to delay and confusion.

It has been our practice to send forward to the Purchasing Agent, from time to time, a list of the requisitions that had been placed with him and the dates when these requisitions were sent forward. The Purchasing Agent was also reminded on such occasions that deliveries had not been made. The officials inform me that, when they did this, they were of the opinion that such action was all that was expected from them.

I am attaching hereto copy of the memorandum sent forward on June 10, the original of which, Mr. Jackson states, is not on record at the office of the Purchasing Agent.

May I suggest that it might be advisable to bring together again in conference the officials of this Branch interested in purchasing, with the Purchasing Agent and with Mr. Jackson. I am of the opinion that in the purchase and delivery of departmental supplies, greater use might be made of our field officials, particularly our inspectors. In respect to the particular purchase now under review, it is difficult for me to overlook the fact that we have a senior official at Calgary and no less than three Indian agents close to the city of Edmonton, any one or all of whom might have been asked to see that delivery of this particular lighting plant was made and that it reached Waterways prior to the close of navigation.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR OPERATION OF DIESEL ENGINE DRIVEN BATTERY CHARGER

These instructions cover a diesel engine driven 4½ kilowatt, direct current, battery charging generator set, arranged for V belt drive and mounted on a common cast iron base plate.

This assembly is indicated on drawing #5-2 attached hereto.

Engine

Detailed instructions covering the engine are enclosed in a tin packing case with the unit.

The engine is a Model "IDE", serial number 46967, full diesel, of the 4 stroke cycle type, suitable for operating on fuel oil having a B.T.U. value of not less than 19,000 B.T.U's per pound, with a viscosity not exceeding 50 Seconds Redwood No. 1 at 100 degrees F.

The engine is fitted with full pressure lubrication, utilizing a gear driven lubricating oil pump, and means for adjusting this pressure are fully described in the engine operating instructions.

The engine will develop 8½ h.p. continuously for 12 hours at 1000 r.p.m., and 9½ h.p. for a period of 1 hour. It is of the single cylinder type having a cylinder bore of 4-1/8", and a stroke of 6", giving a mean piston speed of 1000 ft. per minute. The engine has a compression ratio of 16½ to 1, with a mean effective pressure of 84 lbs. per square inch. The guaranteed fuel oil consumption will not exceed .45 pounds per b.h.p. hour, and the lubricating oil consumption is approximately .034 pints per hour.

The engine is fitted with a sensitive fly-ball type governor mounted on the crank shaft, and has a special fly-wheel to provide for close speed and voltage regulation.

Means for starting and stopping this engine manually are clearly indicated in the instruction book accompanying the engine.

A price parts list is attached hereto.

Generator

The generator has a rating of 5 kilowatts, direct-current, compound wound, for 1750 r.p.m., 125 volts, 40 amperes.
It is of the British Thomson-Houston type DY, Frame No. 2816, descriptive list 2252-1, and as per outline diagram ED-7288, all of which are attached hereto.

A field rheostat is provided and mounted on the switchboard to maintain the unit at proper operating conditions and to prevent overload being put on the engine. Under no condition is the amperage rating of the generator to be exceeded, and the rheostat must be adjusted to maintain the output of the generator within this rating, otherwise the generator and engine will become overloaded.

The generator is mounted on slide rails which form an integral part of the cast iron base plate. Adjustment is provided to permit removal of the V belt and the maintaining of same at the correct tension. The slide rails must be set so that there is approximately a total movement of 1" of the V belt when the unit is stationary.

V Belt Drive

V Belt Drive consists of 4 D42 texropes driving a 5.7" pitch diameter sheave on the generator and being driven by a 10" pitch diameter sheave on the engine flywheel.

Switchboard

The switchboard consists of an ebony asbestos panel mounted on pipe supports and designed for a maximum capacity of 5 kilowatts, 125 volts, 40 amperes.

On the switchboard there is provided the following equipment:

2 - Ground detector lamp receptacles
1 - Miniature style, 150 volt, D.C. Indicating Voltmeter
1 - 60 amp D.C. Indicating Ammeter, miniature style
1 - 60 amp. 250 volt, D.P.S.T. open knife switch with fuse clips
1 - 50 amp., 140 volt, type V-1 Hartman Cutout for battery charging.

There is also provided a starting rheostat so that the engine can be cranked from the batteries and thus obviate the necessity of hand cranking. This battery starting is accomplished by, first of all, turning the generator field rheostat counterclockwise as far as it will go in order that the generator will not take an excessive quantity of current from the battery. Next, make sure that the engine injection system is solid, as described in the engine manual, and that the exhaust valve is lifted off its
seat by means of the decompression lever, as described in the engine manual. The engine is now ready to be cranked and this is accomplished by gradually lifting the lever on the cranking rheostat until the engine begins to turn over. Once the engine is turning over the cranking rheostat lever must be dropped to its original position and the compression lever lowered to the stop, which will then permit of the engine starting to fire. Once the engine starts to fire and comes up to speed, the generator field rheostat must be adjusted to the proper position for charging. This is accomplished by turning the rheostat in a clockwise rotation.

Cooling

Cooling is accomplished by the thermo siphon principle and the cooling tank should be set up as indicated in drawing F-2 attached hereto. Sufficient piping is provided to make the necessary connections to suit the actual location.

Exhaust Line

This should be run in as straight a line as possible and with as few turns as is possible. A suitable muffler is provided for the engine exhaust.

Features.

- 240 HOURS OF WORKING ON 1 GALLON OF LUBRICATING OIL.
- Valves removable without disturbing cylinder head or breaking pipe joints.
- Immediate starting from cold, BY HAND, without any ignition or pre-heating device.
- All working parts totally enclosed. Wear through dust or dirt completely eliminated.
- Little or no attention required after starting.

SPECIFICATION

GENERAL.—The engine is of the four cycle, cold starting, solid injection, vertical type. All working parts are totally enclosed, but easy of access.

BEDPLATE AND COLUMN.—Strongly ribbed, separate castings with large inspection doors, giving easy access to all working parts. The column carries the renewable cylinder liner which is left free for expansion at the lower end.

MAIN BEARINGS.—Adjustable, one being provided on each side of the crankshaft. Shellac and phosphor bronze lined with best quality white metal, and give large bearing surfaces.

CRANKSHAFT.—Of Siemens's Martin Acid Process Steel in excess of Lloyd's requirements. Balance weights are fitted, and the shaft is extended at the governor end to take the starting handle.

CYLINDER HEAD.—A detachable head of oval design (Patent No. 361202) is fitted, in which the high degree of turbulence obtained gives perfect combustion at all loads and speeds. It is of a special chrome alloy cast iron.

CYLINDER LINER.—Renewable, of special close grained cast iron, honed to finished diameter.

PISTON AND PIN.—Of close grained cast iron, specially designed for working in conjunction with the patent cylinder head. The pin is casehardened and ground to size.

CONNECTING ROD.—Forged from Siemens's Martin Acid Process Mild Steel, circular section, and drilled for lubricating the small end under pressure. The large end is adjusted by being fitted with loose shells, white metal lined. The small end is fitted with a phosphor bronze bush.

VALVES.—Horizontally disposed in the cylinder head. The inlet valve is carried in a renewable cage, whilst the exhaust valve operates in a renewable guide. Both valves can be removed without disturbing the cylinder head, or breaking any pipe connections or joints of any kind.

VALVE GEAR.—The valves are operated by a camshaft in the crankcase, vertical pushrods and rockers, all totally enclosed, but easy of access. The valve are of the mushroom type and, like the cams, are casehardened and ground.

FUEL PUMP AND ATOMISER.—The pump unit is self contained, whilst the atomiser is of the self-cleaning type.

FLYWHEEL.—On the crankshaft, the boss forming a half coupling for connecting to a dynamo or pulley. The standard wheel is suitable for industrial purposes, whilst for D.C. electrical work a heavier wheel is available giving a cyclic irregularity of 1° 90'. This engine is also available for A.C. work.

GOVERNOR.—Of the totally enclosed centrifugal type, and mounted on the crankshaft. The speed can be adjusted, within limits, whilst the engine is working.

LUBRICATION.—Forced fed by means of a plunger type pump. Pressure is adjusted by a by-pass valve and a gauge is fitted on the engine.

STARTING.—Compression release gear is provided for hand starting and cold. Starting is immediate, no pre-heating device of any kind being required.

COOLING.—The standard arrangement is by thermo-syphon. The engine can also be supplied with a plunger type pump, running at quarter engine speed, for marine auxiliary service. In addition, we can supply radiator cooling equipment consisting of a radiator with cowl and fan, belt driven from the engine.

CONSTRUCTIONAL DETAILS.

The constructional features are generally similar throughout the range, with the exception of the endshields of the two smaller sizes (see illustrations). The constructional differences and those sizes which are suitable for the different enclosures are indicated separately in the table given on page 5.

POLES. Laminations of steel punchings are used for the main poles; the commutating poles are solid of high-grade magnetic iron; the poles are each secured to the frame by two bolts.

FIELD WINDINGS. The field coils are former wound and completely taped up and water-proofed. Any coil can readily be taken off the pole piece after the latter has been removed from the frame. The commutating pole windings are wound direct on the pole with a layer of insulating material between the winding and the core; and finally completely taped.

ARMATURE (see Fig. 4). The core consists of laminations of sheet iron of high permeability, slotted on the periphery to receive the windings and clamped under pressure between substantial end flanges. The laminations are coated with insulating compound before assembly to minimize eddy currents. The armature coils are adequately secured in place by strong binding bands.

The commutator is composed of hard drawn copper segments and mica, and has ample cooling surface. In the larger sizes cooling is assisted by ventilating slots in the shell.

The complete armature is vacuum dried and then treated with special moisture-proof compound to render it immune from the effects of damp when put into service.

Page 2
BRUSHGEAR. The mica insulated brushgear is of substantial construction, and designed with particular regard to the ease and rapidity with which renewals and adjustments can be made. The brush pigtails and machine leads are attached to the same terminals on the brush box, so that the pressure finger and the brush box are not required to carry current. The pressure of any brush is practically uniform throughout the life of the brush, and is readily adjustable without the use of tools.

ENDSHIELDS AND ENCLOSURES. The endshields are of strong construction, provided with ample ventilating openings. They are spigoted to the frame and the bearing housing is bored and accurately ground to size to take the ball or roller bearings. The endshield facings are machined so that the various covers fit closely.

It should be noted that the ratings of the machine are based on certain definite types of enclosure. If, therefore, one type of enclosure is changed for another type, the rating, or temperature rise, or both, may be modified by such a change. Furthermore, totally-enclosing covers must not be fitted to machines designed for other types of enclosure without modifications to the field windings.

BEARINGS. Roller bearings are fitted at the driving end and ball bearings at the commutator end. The ball bearing at the non-driving end serves to take a limited amount of endthrust. The outer races of the bearings are clamped between heavy cast-iron bearing caps. Grease lubrication is used and wide-faced sealing glands effectively retain the grease and prevent the entry of dirt.

HIGH POTENTIAL TESTS. Before the machine is dispatched from the Works it is required to pass the high potential tests as laid down in British Standard Specification No. 168/1936.

TOTALLY-ENCLOSED FAN-COOLED MOTORS.

Totally-enclosed motors, especially the larger sizes, are considerably reduced in output (as compared with ventilated motors) when running continuously at standard temperature rises.

To obviate this they can be supplied fitted with an external fan protected by an outer hood which deflects the air drawn in by the fan over the outer surface of the machines.

By this means the motor is cooled without losing its totally-enclosed feature, and this results in a greatly increased output, particularly at the higher speeds. The passage of air to the fan should not be restricted by a solid pulley or coupling.

Dear Mr Phelan,

With reference to my letter of the last July 26th regarding the lighting plant for the Indian Residential school of Fort Providence, I am enclosing herewith vouchers in triplicate together with invoices in triplicate covering purchases made by us, as was mentioned in my letter referred above.

As this amount has not been paid by us to the Bruce-Robinson Electric Ltd., we would appreciate it if you would have the cheque mailed direct to that firm in Edmonton.

We may say that we have been greatly disappointed to learn that the plant itself which the Dept of Mines and Resources purchased from the General Electric Co. arrived at Waterways much too late to be shipped to Fort Providence by the Transportation Company. We have been informed that the batteries arrived at Waterways on last September 14th, while the engine, dynamo, switchboard and all the power house equipment arrived on September 22nd.

In his telegram to Bishop Breynat of the last July 7th, Dr H. McGill said that the General Electric Co. had been requested to rush delivery of this material. We feel that, in this instance, the General Electric Co. has been exceptionally slow in delivering it. The consequence for us is that the installation of the electric lighting plant for Providence has to be postponed until next summer, the first transportation boat that reaches Providence after the break-up arriving there usually around June 20th. The plant and batteries cannot be there before that time. We think it is useless to send the electrician for the installation, as he could only make half of the job, moreover the school would have no electric lighting at all, even though the wiring would have been done this fall.

After Bishop Breynat called at your office last August on his way to Europe, he wrote me and informed me that, even after everything would have been paid for the electric lighting plant and installation at Ft-Providence, there would still

Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, ONT.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We thank you very much for the information contained in your letter of the 6th inst., advising us that it is not customary for the Department to supply farm machinery to Residential Schools and, therefore, that you cannot secure the threshing machine requested in our letter of October 31st, 1940 for the Fort Resolution Residential School.

However, in the last paragraph of the above mentioned letter, you intimate that we should let you know what equipment or repairs are required for the additional funds available for the Fort Providence School. In this connection, we take pleasure in attaching hereto a quotation just received from the Bruce-Robinson Electric Ltd.

On reading the attached letter, you will see that we have asked for a refrigerating unit which would enable us to keep meat at the Fort Providence School during the spring and summer. After listening to various proposals, we found out that this refrigerating unit would fill our requirements for this place. It will be much less costly than an ordinary ice-house and we do not need more cubic feet to store the average quantity of meat that we need.

Up to the present time we have not had any refrigerating system for the Fort Providence School and we feel that if the Department would have funds available for the purchase of this type of refrigerator, it will greatly assist us in having meat for the children of the school at any time of the year.

We feel confident that you will take our suggestion into consideration and, if so, we anticipate hearing favorably from you in this connection.

Yours very truly,

The R. C. Episcopal Corporation of MacKenzie,

per

J. Serrurier, o.m.i.,
Bursar.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am directed by Archbishop Breynat to answer your letter of the 17 ultimo which was in reference to a letter written to him on June 2 by Honourable Mr. Crerar, Minister of Mines and Resources.

In his letter of May 24 to Honourable Mr. Crerar, Archbishop Breynat was referring to your letter addressed to the writer under the date of April 28 in reply to mine of April 25 sent to you. Pursuant to our previous correspondence, His Excellency was asking the Honourable Minister to have funds allotted for repairs and equipment at the four schools located within the MacKenzie Diocese especially earmarked for the two schools at Fort Chipewyan (Holy Angels) and Akleivik; and in my letter of April 25 referred above I was informing you that this would be for the purpose of purchasing an electric power plant for the new school being actually rebuilt at Fort Chipewyan also for repairs urgently needed for the roof at the Akleivik school.

In your letter of the 17 ultimo you are asking the Archbishop to forward you at the earliest possible date detailed information regarding the materials that he may require, as all purchases have to be made through your Purchasing Branch. In this view, I am directed by Archbishop Breynat to inform you that the necessity in which we have found ourselves to secure the materials without fail coupled with the absolute need of having them delivered on time to their ultimate destination during the summer season had given us no other option than to purchase these materials ourselves instead of complying with the usual practice to have same purchases made through your Purchasing Branch.

You will indeed recall that on April 28 you were not in a position yet to give us definite information regarding total amount that may be available this year for each school and it would have been too late to wait for your letter of June 17 before placing these orders. Naturally, in ordinary times there would have been no difficulty in securing necessary materials, but anyone who has to make purchases this year is aware of new and more drastic regulations being constantly enforced day by day regarding purchases in hardware, electrical supplies and lumber. Being confronted by such a dilemma, Archbishop Breynat decided that he could not take the risk of being unable to secure the materials which he would have, in normal times, purchased through your Purchasing Branch and he feels certain that, in all fairness, you will understand these circumstances.

Mr. Hoey has forwarded for our attention, without written comment, the three attached files, with invoices and correspondence in connection with the placing by the R.C. Church authorities of three orders for equipment and supplies for two church-owned Indian Residential Schools at a total cost of $2,744.56, f.o.b., Waterways, Alta.

Fort Chipewyan (Holy Angels):

From Bruce Robinson Electric Ltd. $2,065.88

Aklavik:

From J.M. Ashdown Hardware Co. Ltd. $354.88
From Holmes Products Corporation Ltd. $324.06

Total...........$2,744.56

The following is a summary of information gleaned from these files:

(a) Letter June 2nd, 1942, signed by Mr. Crerar, authorizing transfer of funds provided for four church-owned northern Indian Residential Schools to be used exclusively for repairs to the Fort Chipewyan and Aklavik Schools.

(b) June 17th, 1942, letter from Mr. Hoey to Bishop Breynat requesting bill of material so that orders could be placed through the Purchasing Division.

(c) June 20, 1942, letter from Father Serrurier to Mr. Hoey advising that orders for the required material had already been placed by the R.C. church authorities with their reason for so doing.

(d) July 26, 1942, letter from Mr. Hoey to Father Serrurier requesting invoices and expressing regret that Departmental purchasing regulations were not followed.
My comment is as follows:

(1) The unit prices charged by J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co., Edmonton, for the roofing material, and by McInnes Products Corporation, Waterways, Alberta, for dimension lumber are fair and reasonable. This material was for use in repairing the Klavik school.

(2) The chief item of expenditure for the Holy Angels School at Fort Chipewyan was an electric lighting plant consisting of a Lister Diesel engine, generator, steel base, switch board, etc., at $1,452.00. The balance $613.89 was spent in electric fixtures and supplies for wiring. The money was voted for necessary repair work, but was spent on new equipment of non-essential classification.

(3) No convincing reasons are given for placing the orders contrary to Mr. Hoey's instructions, and without reference to this office.

In view of the above, will you please advise if you wish us to arrange for payment of the accounts in question.

[Signature]

Departmental Purchasing Agent.
MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill

Will you please note the attached memorandum I have received from the Purchasing Agent in reference to the purchase of certain electric lighting equipment for the Holy Angels School at Fort Chipewyan at a cost of $2,065.68. I have had an opportunity of going over your file and it would seem quite clear that the Church authorities proceeded to purchase this equipment without receiving any authority from your Branch to do so. It is noted in Father Serrurot's letter of the 20th July that the purchase was made at least prior to May 21st for he stated in this letter that he had invoices of this date in his possession. While it is true that Father Serrurot advised you in his letter of the 25th April that some of these funds would serve for purchasing an electric power plant for Fort Chipewyan, he was never advised that the Department would approve of the purchase being made. If the requisition had been forwarded to this office as is the usual procedure, I am sure the Minister would not have approved of it without first ascertaining the reason why this substantial purchase was being made in war-time. There is no information on file to show why the existing equipment could not have been repaired and used until the war was over.

Under the circumstances, therefore, in view of the fact that no authority was given to the Church to make the purchase, the Minister suggests they should be advised that they will have to look after the account themselves.

It is to be regretted that in answering Father Serrurot's letter of the 25th April, you did not advise him that you would not approve of any of the money being spent in the purchase of electric lighting equipment until you were furnished with the reasons why it was needed at this time.

Dear Father Serrurrot:

Invoices and vouchers amounting to a total of $6,744.56, sent forward by you and representing supplies and equipment purchased for the above-noted schools, were submitted by this Branch to the Purchasing Division for the issuance of the usual purchase order. The Director is in receipt of a memorandum from Mr. C. T. Jackson, Chief Executive Assistant, dated September 18, 1945, in which Mr. Jackson states:

Will you please note the attached memorandum I have received from the Purchasing Agent, in reference to the purchase of certain electric lighting equipment for the Holy Angels School at Fort Chipewyan at a cost of $6,685.68. I have had an opportunity of going over your file and it would seem quite clear that the church authorities proceeded to purchase this equipment without receiving any authority from your branch to do so. It is noted in Father Serrurrot's letter of the 20th July that the purchase was made at least prior to May 1st, for he stated in this letter that he had invoices of this date in his possession. While it is true that Father Serrurrot advised you in his letter of the 3rd April that some of these funds would serve for purchasing an electric power plant for Fort Chipewyan, he was never advised that the Department would approve of the purchase being made. If the requisition had been forwarded to this office, as is the usual procedure, I am sure the Minister would not have approved of it without first ascertaining the reason why this substantial purchase was being made in war-time. There is no information on file to show why the existing equipment could not have been repaired and used until the war was over.

Under the circumstances, therefore, in view of the fact that no authority was given to the Church to make the purchase, the Minister suggests they should be advised that they will have to look after the account themselves.

The Minister approves of the expenditures that are made for the school at Aklatik amounting to $675.68.

In view of the above decision, I am returning here-with the Bruce Robinson Electric accounts amounting to $6,065.68.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, February 1, 1945.

Dear Sister Mary Mack:

At the request of Father Plourde, we asked the Purchasing Agent on June 19, 1944, to secure one washer with wringer and electric motor, D.C., 110 Volts, for the Providence Mission Residential School. The order was placed with Stanley Brock, Limited, Winnipeg, Man., on July 8, 1944, and they were requested to make certain that this washer would reach Waterways before the close of navigation. They were also instructed to forward their account to you, so that you could certify it and return for payment as soon as the washer arrived.

As yet we have not received the account, and as the end of the fiscal year is approaching we are extremely anxious to have the account immediately, if the washer has been delivered, in order that payment may be made from this year's appropriation.

If you have received the washer but have not received the account, you should advise me at once to that effect, and we can then adjust the matter with the Stanley Brock Company, as it may take too long to write the firm and have them send the account to you and have it returned before the end of March.

On the other hand, if you have not received the washer, you should immediately advise this office, as in that case, too, we will have to take up the matter with the company. Your immediate reply is requested.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Principal,

We have your favor of the 19th inst., with regard to Purchase Orders No. 1570 and No. 1572. At this point we would like to mention that Orders No. 1571 and No. 1970 were also received from the Department of Mines and Resources for shipment to the Bishop.

We are sorry to advise that none of these goods have been shipped as yet. We do not think it advisable to make part shipments, as it involves extra bookwork on your part as well as our own, and if we make all one shipment it would be much better all the way around.

As we have not yet received our car of Donnacoma wallboard, we were unable to make shipment at the end of March. However, you may rest assured that this material will go down the River on the first boat, and as the goods are only going to Providence and Resolution, there will not be any tie-up on delivery. We do not expect our car of Donnacoma until the end of April, but the first boats will not run until at least May 10th. There would be really no necessity of getting this material down to Waterways in March, as there is the danger of flood conditions, which would definitely spoil the material. We have been shipping material to the North for a great number of years, and we have always had to watch this point.

We hope we have not put you to any great inconvenience, and you may rest assured that just as soon as shipment has been made, we will get the invoice in to you.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

As the annual grant accorded by the Department to our Indian Residential School at Fort Providence is listed as $800.00, I would like to submit a further requisition at this time, in view of the fact that the set of batteries ordered for Fort Providence amounts to only $409.50, as per the purchase order received in this connection.

On the accompanying sheet, I have listed a number of articles required by the school at Fort Providence, as per information received from the school principal. If these can be obtained, or at least a portion of them, to complete the grant for this year, such action would be greatly appreciated by us.

We would be glad to know, also, if there are any of the items listed, which cannot be procured for this year, so as to have an exact idea of just what may be expected.

Very truly yours,

J. Trocellier O.M.I.,
Vicer Apostolic of Mackenzie,
Titular Bishop of Adramyttium.
Providence Residential School
Providence, June 30th, 1946.

Kind Mr Phelan:

I have the pleasure to inform you that I have received the school articles on June 21st. I was very pleased to receive the goods forwarded, as I was badly in need of them.

My sincere thanks, kind Mr Phelan for granting me the favor of making those purchases.

I appreciate very much your benevolence in this matter, and I thank you also for the great interest you take in the welfare of our schools.

May the Good God reward you for all.

Sincerely yours,

Sr Cecile Baron, S.G.M.
Principal

March 1, 1947.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Your letter of February 25th has been received, and we thank you for the permission accorded us to purchase in Edmonton the articles listed in your letter of October 17, 1946. The order will go forward today, to our suppliers, Marshall Wells and Company, Ltd., with the request that the account be made out at once, so that we may forward it to you well before the end of the present month.

We appreciate also the exception you have made in our favor regarding the two tents, two stoves and two clocks. Personally we believe the two clocks are not absolutely required, and the two tents (size 14 x 18 was requested) are practically out of the question at the present time, considering the difficulty of procuring good tents of any kind at reasonable prices. Therefore, we will leave out the tents and the clocks.

A few days ago, we learned that it will be possible to purchase two good portable camp stoves right here in Fort Smith, for a total of $37.50, which included the necessary stove pipes. Since your permission has been granted for this purchase - in Edmonton - we are having these two stoves and pipes held over for us, until we hear that we may purchase them here in Fort Smith. The two stoves are perfectly new, and we consider the price reasonable.

As for the goods being ordered from Marshall Wells, these will be kept in their warehouse until navigation opens in May.

Thanking you for your kind consideration of these requisitions, we remain,

very truly yours,

R.C. Missions of Mackenzie,
per Charles Miller, Bursar.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We have at length secured the articles you permitted us to purchase for Sacred Heart School, Fort Providence, and we are immediately returning the accounts covering cost of same.

At Marshall-Wells Ltd., in Edmonton, we were able to get the various articles originally requested, and approved by Mr. Neary in his letter to Father Mansoz, Fort Smith, Oct. 17, 1946.

At the local Hudson's Bay Company post we procured the two camp stoves along with 5 lengths of pipe for each stove, so that both would be ready for installation upon delivery. We should explain the date on the H.B.C. account. Actually the purchase was made on March 1, the clerk explaining that March 1, which was a Saturday, was included in the last week of February, as far as their books were concerned. Almost immediately after we had written you on March 1, we learned that someone in the Fort was looking for camp stoves in view of the spring hunt, and to offset the possibility that another clerk might sell the two stoves being held for us, we thought best to make the purchase at once. It was perhaps best that we did, as we found, upon returning, that these two stoves were the only ones left.

Thanking you again for your consideration in assisting us to obtain these items during the fiscal year about to close, we remain,

very truly yours,

R.C. Missions of Mackenzie,

April 30, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your voucher No. 523 covering the cost of transportation by aeroplane of three children from Fort Simpson to the Providence Mission Indian Residential School. Please let me know why it was necessary to send these children by aeroplane. Could not arrangements have been made to keep them at their home until some cheaper method of transportation was available? Due to a reduction in our appropriation the Department cannot consider payment of aeroplane transportation for Indian children unless there are some extremely exceptional circumstances.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. W.A.M. Truesdell,
Indian Agent,
Fort Simpson, N.W.T.
Fort Simpson, N.W.T., June 1, 1940.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of April 30, file 139-3-10, I beg to say that the three children mentioned as having been transported to Fort Providence by aeroplane were the children of Mrs. George Wrigley, who was frozen to death during the month of December, and they had no living relative able to support them in Fort Simpson. They would have had to be kept at the hospital until the first boat, as I could find no other accommodation for them in Fort Simpson. Therefore, I deemed it best to send them to the school at Fort Providence, where I know they are being well cared for.

Hoping this explains the necessity for this expenditure, I am,

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Ottawa, Ont.
