Fort Simpson, N.W.T., May 15, 1941.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Feb. 25, file 139-3-10, received by me on our last winter mail, I beg to say that pupils No. 195 Frank Moses, No. 230 Jimmy Villeneuve, No. 233 Baptiste Nakakon and No. 0220 Liza Sambele were given holidays during the summer months and were kept at home by their parents for the winter to help at home and as company for other children. I learned this during my short trip to Fort Providence in the winter to see patients at the school and in the village, and, of course, it was too late then to insist that they return to school. I have been opposed to children being allowed to go home from the school any considerable distance for the summertime as we always have the same trouble in getting them back to school in the fall. I am always away on my treaty paying trips in the summer when the bishop's boat calls at Fort Simpson, and he no warning about the children who are being returned for a summer holiday to their homes, as there is no mail available at the time that his boat calls at Providence and decisions to send them are usually made on the spur of the moment according to the amount of space available on the boat.

I have taken the matter up with the Father in charge at Fort Providence, and the Father in charge at Fort Simpson, and in future I am to be given full information concerning those children who will have summer holidays at their homes.

In the case of Catherine Denicoche No. 0250, this girl was admitted to the school and examined by myself last October, and application form should have been forwarded to you from the school Superintendent, Sister Mack. I will take this matter up with her by the first mail, and will inform you further on the matter as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief Training Division,
Ottawa, Ont.

CANADA
Fort Simpson, N.W.T. Sept.28.1942.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing with this letter Applications for admission to the Providence Mission Residential School of eight children examined by me on my recent visit to the school and hope that you will approve of these.

There were many Indians absent from the settlement when I arrived in Providence and I had thus not much of an opportunity to secure more children for the school, and they are below their quota at present. I took the matter up with the Chief and two of the Head Men and they promised to urge others to have their children admitted to the school. I hope we will soon have the number up to the requisite quota.

Also while in Providence I took the matter of the over-age girl, Elizabeth Sabourin, No. 0165, up with the school principal, Sister Mary Mack, and she stated she would write you immediately, and I trust has done so ere now.

Yours very truly

W.A.M. Truesdell, M.D.
Indian Agent.

Providence Residential School
Sept 19th 1943

To Mr Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

Kind Sir,

You have been notified that Sr Mack left Providence in May to visit her family. She was supposed to be back in Sept., but as she needed a few months' rest, Rev Mother General has delayed her departure. I have been appointed to replace her, as I have been here before in the year 1933.

I will do the best of my ability to try to give satisfaction to those who are doing so much for the welfare of our children and especially to you, kind Mr Phelan.

I have an unforeseen case that I wish to submit to your benevolence.

A young Slave girl of 16 years of age in August, came from the bush last week and begged to be taken in school to learn how to read & write. She wishes to remain with us
for a year or so to learn. She added: "All the young girls around here know how to read and write and I know nothing. Please take me in the School." Her demand was so touching that Sr Superior has taken her in School. I have not written her name in the Report unless you advise me to do so.

Hoping to receive a favorable answer

I remain

Yours faithfully,

Sr Cecile Caron,
Acting Principal.
Ottawa,
October 1, 1943.

It is noted that you are Acting Principal of this school during the absence of Sister Mack.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
